Speaker: Mr JENKINS
Title: PROHIBITION AMENDMENT BILL
text: It is an unexpected pleasure to have the opportunity to speak on the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Amendment Bill. Mr Speaker, as you know, this is a very important matter and I take cognisance of the personal explanation you made last night and the context of the comments you made on behalf of the government at the time of the original legislation. had the pleasure of being on the committee that you chaired, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, when it inquired into sports funding and administration. I was a party to the inquiry entitled 'Can Sport be Bought?' That puts me in a difficult situation on this legislation. I support the legislation. I am disappointed that the opposition, while supporting the legislation, has continually taken the opportunity that this debate gives to chastise the government, saying that this is yet another piece of legislation that has been brought in simply to repair problems that have arisen. In the opposition's eyes, the original legislation was put in in haste. I do not think the government has anything to be ashamed of. In regard to the operation of legislation, the government comes into this place to make the necessary improvements to ensure that legislation we have enacted is achieving its aims. I listened with interest to a number of the contributions last night. Unfortunately, I have not had the opportunity to review all the contributions, but I found myself in agreement with many of the points that were made by speakers on both sides. (Quorum formed) I thank the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) for ensuring that I have an audience. The issue of tobacco advertising is important. As honourable members mentioned in the debate last night, throughout this parliament we have put in place-as in an overwhelming number of public buildings-a 1995 ban on smoking. I am a little disappointed that some of my colleagues have not necessarily heeded that ban. I do not want to be described as having a Stalinist attitude to this issue, but if it is good enough for other people who work in this building to do the right thing, under the directive of the Speaker and the President, then honourable members should see their way clear and not put themselves above that sort of ban. I was interested in a number of the comments the honourable member for MCPherson (Mr Bradford) made last night. I was a little shocked and worried that I found myself in I agreement with some of the things he said; Mr Bevis-It is a real worry.

Speaker: Mr JENKINS
Title: PROHIBITION AMENDMENT BILL
text: --The Soccer Federation, which is an important sporting group, came before the inquiry. It had consciously made the decision to have that association, because it saw that as important. Soccer is a sport that is proud of its junior development, and the federation saw it as an appropriate program to be associated with. Likewise, the national basketball team that I have some emotional attachment to, the North Melbourne Giants, has had a long association with various health campaigns. In fact, its association has been on the side of appropriate use of alcohol. For some years, the sponsorship was with the 'Booze less' campaign and now they are associated with the 'Rage without alcohol' campaign. It is important to note that those in the health foundation that provide the money see that it is valuable to be associated with sport. We are attempting to not only put forward and challenge some of the views of adults in our community but also ensure that younger people in our society are exposed to a range of values that can be important down the track and in later life. It is intriguing to have a look at the purpose of tobacco advertising. Whilst we have the argument from the tobacco companies that promotion of their separate products is either to protect their market share or to readjust their market share, I would contend that promotion of tobacco in any way must continue to influence especially younger people considering taking up the habit of tobacco smoking. That is a difficulty. That may not be the intention of the companies but there is evidence that it is a consequence of their activities. That is why the legislation we have before us in amending the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992 is important. It is an important way of sending signals to our younger generations that there is a downside to adopting a habit that they might associate with some sort of glamorous lifestyle. As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Theophanous) set out in his second reading speech, looking at the Australian situation, nearly 19,000 deaths in the year that the original legislation was passed were directly associated with tobacco consumption. As he stated, tobacco consumption costs our country approximately $9.24 billion each year in health, social and economic costs. Interestingly, last night the honourable member for Moreton (M!' Gibson) developed that argument in putting a case to double the amount of excise because he recognised that there was an economic downside to people's continued consumption of tobacco produ-ts. In the report of the US Surgeon-General Preventing tobacco use among young people, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Donna Shalala, in her introduction to the report, quoted the statistic for America when she said, 'Smoking kills 434,000 Americans each year.' Taking that American figure and considering activities in other countries around the world, we have a problem of huge dimensions. There is always some direct, but mostly anecdotal, evidence of the way some tobacco companies behave because of contracting markets in more developed countries and their marketing activities in Third World countries. A number of those Third World countries have enormous health problems as it is and they could well do without the pressures of tobacco consumption. So it is important that we view Australia's action in an international dimension. Australia has taken a number of measures at national, state and territory levels which have been seen by overseas countries as important examples of what can be achieved. For example, actions by the Victorian and Western Australian governments highlight active involvement in a wide range of health programs, including those such as the Quit campaign, that try to give people the necessary tools to kick the habit. A number of people I know who smoke acknowledge that they are not doing the right thing by themselves but, because of the addictive nature of the habit, it is very difficult for them to kick the habit. As I have already exposed the attitude of the previous honourable member for Scullin about smoking, in fairness to him I should say one of the contradictions that were brought to my attention on a number of occasions was that in his career as a medical practitioner, one of the first things he quite often did when advising people was to tell them to stop smoking. When I was down the street or around a polling booth, which is when it seemed to happen a lot, people would come up to me and talk about having visited Dr Harry. They said that one of the things that intrigued them was that whilst they felt so much better now that they had been able to kick the habit-(Quorum formed) To finish that anecdote, the contradiction of course is that the former honourable member for Scullin continues to smoke. I might add that at his time of life, all things being equal, it is probably not a real problein to him any more in that any damage has been done. The fact that the habit enables him to be comfortable is a consideration. This is an important piece of legislation. It is an important activity of government to ensure that problems like tobacco consumption and its effect on the health of the nation are addressed. As the figures set out in the second reading speech show, this is a major problem that needs to be addressed. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr CAMERON
Title: PROHIBITION AMENDMENT BILL
text: Stirling) (9.53 a.m.)Today we are debating the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Amendment Bill which seeks to restrict the right of companies to advertise a product which they can legally sell. I think it is ironic that the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) is associated with this legislation. She is seen by many as a person that many young people would look up to in Western Australia, in fact all over Australia. Mr Johns-They do, too.

Speaker: Mr CAMERON
Title: PROHIBITION AMENDMENT BILL
text: I am sure they do. It is ironic, therefore, that the minister was shown in the Sunday Times newspaper in Perth not so long ago indulging in the unhealthy habit of smoking. In the paper was a photo of 'Puffing Carmen' with a smoke hanging out of her mouth. What a great advertisement for the tobacco companies to have had the then Premier puffmg away on the front of a widely read family newspaper! She is looked up to by many people. I believe the minister has now given up the filthy habit, for which I congratulate her. Nevertheless I hope the fact that she was seen puffing away did not encourage others to smoke. We also had a photograph on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald of a gentleman who is not flavour of the month with the Australian Labor Party at the moment-Kerry Packer---on his way to rugby league headquarters, puffing on a cigarette. One would have thought with his recent health problems that that was not the way to go. If he keeps that up perhaps he will not be a threat to the media of Australia. Two years after the minister for health was seen promoting a habit she was addicted to, she legislates to prohibit its promotion. I speak as a father and grandfather and as one who does not smoke. I have two daughters who used to smoke but, thankfully, they do not any more. One of my daughters is a nurse and she knows of a person who has had all four limbs amputated as a direct result of smoking. Yet, with the stumps of her arms, this woman was still able to put a cigarette her mouth and smoke. This highlights the harmful effects of smoking, the obvious difficulty with forcing people to quit and the definite need to prevent people from taking up the habit. Once people are addicted, it is terribly difficult to break that addiction. There is no doubt that smoking is a death warrant. A cigarette is a lethal, slow killing drug. It is important for us to reduce smoking amongst all Australians. A report of the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, entitledAustralia's Health 1994, stated that a most alarming trend is the rapid rise in female lung cancer since the 1960s. The age-standardised death rate rose 5.7 per 100,000 in 1966 to 17.5 per 100,000 in 1992 as a result of women's increased cigarette consumption since the 1940s. There have been declines in lung cancer death rates in men but they remain three times those of women. The proportion of men smoking declined through the 1980s and into the 1990s, and it is expected this will reduce men's lung cancer death rates over the next decade. Smoking rates in women have also declined, but at a slower rate, which may curb the increase in women's lung cancer death rates. There is no doubt about the dangers of smoking. Worse is the frightening statistics about the number of potential cancer victims: that is, young people who smoke and are therefore at a greater risk of getting cancer. The Centre of Behavioural Research into Cancer recently reported an alarming increase in smoking among 13to 17-year-olds. There are now 260,000 secondary school children smoking about 330 million cigarettes, which is costing them $49 million. The Minister for Human Services and Health made us aware of these awful statistics during question time on Monday. Teenage smoking, after initially falling, is again on the rise. The question is: why do people smoke and what starts them smoking? Is it advertising? Is it peer pressure? Is it the tastethough I doubt it---or is it part of all of those and other factors? If it is not advertising, this bill and the act it amends will be useless because, three to five years down the in track, young people will still be smoking. Men and women will still be dying from smoking. I am confident that anti-smoking campaigns and promotions do work and should be continued. In fact, I believe they could be a bit more forthright, like many of our drinkdriving advertisements. They could go along the lines of, 'If you smoke, you're a bloody idiot and you're going to die.' You have to spell it out that bluntly. It is an effective advertisement to stop drink-driving and it would be an even better anti-smoking advertisement. I am not sure whether this bill or the act it amends will be effective. How many kids are influenced to smoke by looking at a sign at the cricket mentioning a brand name of some cigarettes? How many people are actually encouraged to smoke because they have seen a glossy advertisement in the Women's Weekly of a young man and woman on the beach with a cigarette in their hands? Frankly, I do not think cigarette advertising encourages smoking to the extent that perhaps some people think. I am prepared to support this bill if the government thinks it will discourage smoking, and I will support most measures to discourage the habit. In saying that, let me also stress my concern about the inhibition of freedom of speech. I am a great believer and supporter of freedom of speech. While I have no trouble supporting this bill, I still feel a touch hypocritical supporting a bill which prohibits the right of a business to sell a legally available product. The honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) last year was condemned for making similar comments. She was condemned by the minister for health, the AMA and the Doctors Reform Society. The latter group would perhaps be better known as the Association of Labor Doctors. I had some sympathy for the member for Mackellar. The minister for health was sprouting the dangers of smoking, saying that we need to prevent smoking, that cigarettes are deadly drugs which cost the whole community and so on. Well, if she is so concerned about it, why is she not campaigning for tobacco to be an illegal product? Why ban the as? It is the smokes that kill, not the commercials. It comes back to what the former member for Wentworth, John Hewson, talked about on Monday: honesty and politics. If we are all honest with ourselves, smoking would be illegal.

Speaker: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
Title: PROHIBITION AMENDMENT BILL
text: She doesn't smoke any more.

Speaker: Mr CAMERON
Title: PROHIBITION AMENDMENT BILL
text: I believe she has kicked the habit. But, being politicians, we need the money from taxes on smokes and we are afraid we will lose votes if we prohibit the sale of tobacco. As well, we will simply create a big black market for the sale of cigarettes like there is for the more illicit drugs. However, the point I am trying to make is that, if we are to make a significant inroad into preventing smoking, it is not the prevention of advertising of tobacco that will achieve itthough it may make a small contribution. If the minister for health was honest about the facts, it is smoking that should be prohibited, not the advertising of it. By prohibiting smoking advertising, are we reducing the number of people who smoke? Do not get me wrong, I do not like smoking. If prohibiting tobacco advertising saves lives then, notwithstanding my support for freedom of speech, I will support the bill. But, at the end of the day, will the measure be effective? Will it greatly reduce smoking? A survey of Victorian school students in 1992 found that the most prevalent drugs used by students were licit drugs-pain relievers, alcohol and tobacco--which were also perceived by students as the least dangerous drugs. It is unfortunate that people so young are taking up the habit, in the belief that smoking is not dangerous. The survey also revealed that, by year 11, 78 per cent of students had tried smoking and 24 per cent were. regular daily smokers. In year 9, females smoked proportionally more than males. However, by year 11, the gender difference had disappeared. These statistics are certainly a worry. It is therefore important for the government to do its utmost to discourage smoking by all people, in particular to prevent young people taking up the habit. Such preventative campaigns are much more effective than prohibiting companies advertising a legal product. Many advertisements in Western Australia have been aimed at discouraging smoking. I believe the falling number of smokers is a result of them, and I am more comfortable supporting these campaigns first. I conclude by making a number of points to prevent my being misrepresented. I fully and unequivocally support free speech. I do not like smoking and will support most measures to reduce smoking and therefore save lives. lone day hope that the vast majority of, if not all, Australians choose not to smoke without the need for prohibition. Having enunciated my reservations with it, I nevertheless do not oppose this legislation.

Speaker: Mr HAVILAND
Title: PROHIBITION AMENDMENT BILL
text: I am pleased to support the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Amendment Bill, which amends the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992. The amendments to the principal act are, as we have heard, technical in nature-arising from a court case-and seek to clarify the meaning of the act. Tobacco smoking is now widely acknowledged as the major cause of preventable death and disease in Australia. A staggering 19,000 Australians each year die from smoking related illnesses. Tobacco consumption costs Australia the enormous amount of over $9 billion a year in health,social and economic costs. It also causes cardiovascular disease, which is Australia's biggest health problem, and is the largest cause of death from cancer in Australian males. The national health policy on tobacco has the support of all state and territory governments as well as the national government. All governments have a responsibility to take a strong stand towards reducing tobacco consumption, which is why limiting tobacco advertising is so important as we try to discourage young people from smoking. I note with interest that many of the speakers in this debate have related their own personal history of whether they have smoked and how they feel about smoking. I have always considered myself very fortunate in this respect because I have never been a smoker. I have never had any desire to be a smoker. Neither of my parents smoked. I recall that in my very early years my parents influenced me on what a dirty, filthy habit it is. I certainly believe today that it is a dirty, filthy, disgusting habit but, unfortunately, one which some people-including friends of mine-are addicted to. I feel sorry for them. My father smoked for a brief period during the Second World War when he was in the air force but he quickly gave it up after the war. My mother never smoked and, unlike a lot of other children my age at the time, I never had any desire to smoke. In fact, I have always had a very negative view of smoking. In 1960 I was in grade 3 and eight years old. I remember we were shown a film at school which, for the times, was fairly graphic. It showed the lungs of a smoker compared with the lungs of a non-smoker. (Quorum/armed) As I was saying, when I was eight years old, I saw a very graphic film about the evils of smoking, which certainly had a lasting impression on me. It is not as though I needed to see the film because, as I have already explained, I never had any desire to be a smoker. I guess there was a time when, like most teenagers, I was a bit curious about smoking. When I was out with friends, I had a few puffs on a cigarette but, whenever I inhaled, I doubled over and nearly choked. Two or three times after that I tried it again, and the same thing happened. That certainly reinforced my view that smoking was not for me. Because of my total aversion to smoking and my incapability to smoke, I have never had any desire to smoke marijuana. A lot of honourable members have probably tried that from time to time, and I do not pass judgment on them. I have certainly never tried marijuana, for the same reason that I do not smoke cigarettes: inhaling smoke is something that I find repUlsive. All that was back in the 1960s, when I was a teenager. In those days there was not as much public awareness about smoking and the damage that it could cause. There were some reports saying that smoking could cause lung cancer, and we all know that is true. As was revealed the other day in the House, the Menzies cabinet had the opportunity to place restrictions or a ban on tobacco advertising smoking but its members did not think it was necessary. They were more concerned about the profits of the tobacco industry than that of public health in Australia. Like much of what happened during the Menzies years, that is to be regretted. During the 1970s and certainly the 1980s the term 'passive smoking' was introduced into the debate. I think the member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) and the member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) talked about passive smoking. As smoking is not allowed inside this building, a lot of people can be found smoking outside, where the air is more polluted than it is inside. That is a bit of a worry. Basically, even if you are a non-smoker, you still inhale smoke as a result of other people's smoking. During the 1980s there was quite a bit of legal discussion about passive smoking. I recall that one or two workers claimed compensation in the courts for becoming ill as a result of passive smoking. An Attorney General's opinion indicated that an employer may be liable if an employee suffered an illness or a disease as a result of other employees smoking in the workplace. That was a matter of some concern to employers. I remember vividly that in 1986 the federal Department of Health-which is quite appropriate-decided to take the lead and smoking was banned in all the department's workplaces from 1 December 1986. That was the first time this had happened in Australia and the federal Department of Health was a leader in the field. The department's action caused a bit of debate at the time, but it was the decision. Over the years that decision has been confirmed. I was a union delegate in the department in those days. My union certainly supported a smoke free workplace, but we had union members who smoked. There was an attempt to reach a compromise whereby smokers could go off and smoke in a smoking room or whatever. The department took the view that, as the boss had to pay for that, it was not a good way to spend public money. In retrospect, I guess that was the correct view. In 1988 the Australian Public Service as a whole adopted the smoke free workplace, and once again it had the support of the trade union movement, despite the fact that some union members were smokers and had some difficulty with the ban. The anti-smoking debate-particularly the debate about tobacco advertising-was also the subject of some colourful debates within the Australian Labor Party. I can recall that on at least two occasions at the New South Wales annual conference of the Australian Labor Party-which can sometimes be colourful events-a couple of very vigorous debates about tobacco advertising occurred. At the New South Wales conferences most debates are decided on factional lines, no matter what the topic might be or how controversial it might be. The smoking debate was not decided on factional lines. It was a very closely contested debate. The numbers were unusually close in a couple of those debates. There must have been a lot of support for the Left's hardline position on tobacco advertising in those debates. I was an alderman on the Campbelltown City Council and I recall that we had a difficult situation in relation to the Campbelltown sports ground. The Labor council, with the support of progressive independents, wanted to ban smoking in all council buildings-which it did-and wanted to ban advertising at council owned venues. That created a difficulty at Campbelltown sports ground because it is the home ground Of Western Suburbs Rugby League Club. That club plays in the Winfield Cup competition. The club had to have tobacco advertising at right Campbelltown sports ground as part of its qualifications for playing in the competition. That created all sorts of legal and political problems. They were not satisfactorily resolved at the time. The advertising continued. I believe that the passage of this bill and the subsequent phasing out of tobacco advertising will resolve that problem. I support this bill because it is important that we do everything we possibly can to encourage young people not to smokeparticularly in the context of sporting sponsorship. Cricket all over Australia, and rugby league in half of Australia, are amongst the most popular sports, both from a participant and spectator point of view. It seems to me to be unsatisfactory that for many years both of those sports have been sponsored by tobacco companies. I know from experience that both cricket and rugby league administrations have been proud to be associated with the sponsors. They have been loyal sponsors and have provided a lot of money to allow those games to develop. They have been very supportive. Despite that, I believe that it is a bit of a national disgrace that two of our most popular sports-we must remember that sport is about promoting health and fitness and healthy activity-are sponsored by tobacco companies. I will be pleased to see that cease as soon as practicable after the passage of this legislation. Sport is about health and about our future. I believe that not only will the cessation of tobacco advertising for major sport be good for the health of the nation and a positive and progressive step for our health overall but I also believe it is in the long-term interests the sports. Maybe with pay television and the debate surrounding it-with the megabucks coming into carry sport on television-some of this debate might be irrelevant in a few years time. Nevertheless, I think it is in the long-term interests of the sporting codes as well as the health of the nation that. we get tobacco sponsorship out of sport. I know that sponsorship for major sport, especially these days, is very important. Many major sports would not survive without it. But for their long-term benefit, for their long-term ability to survive as sports that attract young people as players and as spectators, it is in their interests not to be associated with products like tobacco. I am very pleased to support this legislation. crops. Hopefully it will clear up some of the problems that seem to have arisen from previous legislation. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr LIEBERMAN
Title: PROHIBITION AMENDMENT BILL
text: Indi) (10.16 am.}- Mr Deputy Speaker, I represent the people who grow tobacco in the state of Victoria. As many honourable members know, there is a very large section of the rural economy in north-eastern Victoria-mainly in Myrtleford and the valleys surrounding it-where, for many years, hard working families have grown tobacco. Many of them were from other countries originally, from Italy particularly. They are very highly respected and good citizens of our nation but they have been the meat in the sandwich in the debate surrounding the use of tobacco in Australia. In fact, until recent changes to the law, could not grow tobacco without having a quota licence, which was issued through the Victorian parliament. We have had this odd situation where, on the one hand, governments, state and federal, have been attempting to persuade people through various ways not to smoke tobacco; on the other hand, federal and state. governments have encouraged farmers to invest their capital and time in farming operations to grow tobacco. So we can see there is something of a paradox there. I have had the difficult task of trying to represent those citizens as they are entitled to be represented, both in my previous life as a state member and now as a federal member. of I wanted to put that on record t6 let honourable members know that there are a lot of very decent people in Australia-farmers who grew tobacco in the past and farmers who still do-who, it should always be remembered, are innocent bystanders in a way and whose rights should be protected and respected. I welcome moves by the state governments and the federal government in the last year or so to assist many farmers to adjust out of tobacco. There is now a complex arrangement between federal and state governments and the manufacturers whereby funds are being made available to assist tobacco farmers to get out of growing tobacco, to sell some of their smaller quotas to larger farmers so there will be fewer growers, and to readjust into other In my area of Indi-in the Myrtleford area and the valleys-we are very excited because of the alternative crops that are now being researched and developed, such as grapes for wine. We already produce the best wines in Australia---':'Milawa, Brown·· Brothers and Rutherglen, which we all know-and now some of the tobacco farmers, some of them third and fourth generation, are plucking up the courage to get into a new crop, and they are doing very well. I predict that the Ovens and King valleys will become very famousmore famous than they are now-as producers of fine wine. We all wish them well. We also have a new industry being developed whereby mint oil is produced. Most of our supplies are imported. Our needs for they confectionary and perfume are virtually all supplied by imported mint oil. Farmers in my electorate in both the areas I have mentioned plus in the upper Murray and Corryong are having a go at producing mint oil. They are doing quite well and it is a fantastic situation. We hope that these farmers who have worked hard in the tobacco industry will find a livelihood and a future for themselves and their children with that crop. It will help our balance of trade figures if we can replace the imported mint oil with Australian produced mint oil. We are also seeing the emergence of high quality vegetable crops. There were some experimental crops of cauliflower grown last season in the Myrtleford area. I amtold that the quality was absolutely phenomenal-the sugar content in all the cauliflowers was amongst the highest that has ever been prothis duced in Australia and the crop ripened couple of weeks earlier than the traditional crop in Australia. Our hope is that enough farmers will work cooperatively, with the assistance of federal and state governments and with some advice and research, to duce sufficient quantities of high quality vegetables so that we can supply some of Australian domestic markets and also win some export markets-flying our fresh tables directly from north-eastern Victoria the Asian markets. There are lots of good things going on. I wanted to weave that brief summary of what is going on and to remind members that there are some pretty decent people involved in this debate. I had a lot to Cancer Council of Victoria as a former After that dateassistant minister for health and minister for health in the state of Victoria. I always appreciated that Dr Nigel Gray always tobacco made it absolutely clear that his campaign to support. have action taken to dissuade people from using tobacco was not directed against the tobacco farmers in any shape or form. I have always appreciated that because it is important for morale and for what is right that these people be treated with great respect. It is in that context that I wanted to mention that, for the last 35 years in Myrtleford, there has been a very famous festival called the tobacco, hops and timber festival. It is a coming together of the community, which is also a centre for the timber and hops tries. The community celebrates its hard work through the year and uses the festivities of festival to raise money for local charities. It is good fun, and everyone gets involved in it. The concern of the festival committee is that, with this legislation-and Susan Bums, the coordinator, has written to me-it will not be possible to continue the festival, firstly because of the name of the festival, the tobacco, hops and timber festival; and, secondly, because the festival's success has been able to be carried on only with the support of some limited, but substantial; sponsorship by the tobacco manufacturers. As you know, the act this bill amends and bill deal with the future ability of people a to acknowledge sponsorships. I have written to the government-the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence)-on this issue on behalf of the festival and the community. I prothank the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr the Theophanous) for his letter of 7 February 1995 in which he says that the existing act vegedoes not prevent the acknowledgment of into sponsors of tobacco manufacturers in the festival. However, it does say that that is the case until the end of 1995. The question the community wanted to raise was: what is the position for the future both under the existing act and the amending bill? I thank the parliamentary secretary for his letter of 7 February do with the Antiin which he stated: shadow that is, the end of 1995companies could still sponsor the Festival receiving in return limited acknowledgment of thei; It seems that the government, through the parliamentary secretary, is acknowledging the relevance and historical nature of the event. The government acknowledges that it will be possible for the festival to continue to be sponsored in part, at least, as I understand it, by the tobacco manufacturers and, for that matter, the tobacco growers that will remain in that area, because it is the governmenf s policy that there will still be tobacco growers in Australia. That is quite firm. Both state and indusfederal governments confirm that. The situation should be cleared up. I would the like the Special Minister of State (Mr Johns) to talk to the minister and also the parliamentary secretary in order to give some further clarification to the future arrangements so that the people do not unwittingly commit a breach of the law. They do not want to do that: they are very law abiding citizens. It is important that we get the position right. I have asked the festival committee to let me have a draft of what it anticipates its program would look like for 1996, a copy of which I propose to send to the government. I will ask the government to have some input into the preparation of the program, because I think we all need to work together to come to a satisfactory conclusion. When I was in the Victorian parliament I assisted in the drafting of an amendment to the Victorian act dealing with the control of advertising of tobacco products. Section 9 of the Victorian Tobacco Act 1987 provided: Nothing in this section shall apply to the annual festival known as the Myrtleford Tobacco Hops Timber Festival. I am very happy to say that the parliament of Victoria almost unanimously supported the continuation of this very important, historical and cultural event. That is still the law in Victoria, despite the changes of governmentthe Cain-Kirner government and now the Kennett government. There is certainly precedent for parliaments to give special acknowledgment to this sort of festival without undermining the basic thrust of the legislation dealing with advertising generally. I felt then and I still feel now that there is a lot of hypocrisy by the governments, past and present, in this debate. They are very quick to take vast sums of money each year by way of tobacco excise tax levies--ever increasing. They use that to fund their basic budgets now. Those taxes are not allocated directly to the health portfolio so that we can expand our health programs. They are gobbled up by the general consolidated revenue appetite, and under Labor, an ever increasing one, and there is no way that this government-and to be honest, there is no way that a government that I hope to be part of soonwill be able to afford to give away in the next decade or so that vast sum of annual income. On the one hand, the government wants to keep the income coming in from the sales of tobacco through excise taxes but, on the other hand, it wants to go through these health programs to persuade people to better look after themselves, and I obviously support those programs. There is no quarrel from my point of view about the need for Australians to improve their health and to avoid activities that will diminish their health. But there is hypocrisy. I found it offensive, to be honest, to be a local member representing tobacco growers in the state parliament and now the federal parliament now that it is legislating to exclude national sporting functions, such as the cricket, that so many Australians enjoy, from application of the prohibition. The legislation provides that these sporting functions can continue to be advertised and sponsored by tobacco companies. But when people who are the salt of the earth, hard working people in and the farming communities, want to seek an exemption for little festivals like this, it is not on. I appreciate the government's response through the parliamentary secretary, but I asked him, 'Why won't the government give a specific exemption like the Victorian act does?' But, no, it seems we cannot do that. We are not allowed to. Translated, that means Myrtleford is too little. It is not significant and it does not have the big muscles of the cricket national television coverage which is allowed, under the present act, to have tobacco sponsorship. I find that hypocritical. I do not accept it as being right. It is time that the parliament picked up the opportunity to be fair to everybody, small fish or large fish, and acknowle,dge that there are some functions, such as the national cricket and other famous sporting events that attract so many visitors to' A ustralia, where there will be a continuation of some sort of sponsorship by manufacturers. The Myrtleford tobacco and hops festival should be treated in the same way. I wonder whether the minister will take that message to his colleagues? It is given in good faith. I am not trying to make it more difficult for government in these matters but it is right, as the local member, that I put the request on record. I think there is a damned good case for the Myrtleford tobacco, hops and timber festival to be given a specific exemption, rather than its having the vagaries of deciding whether from year to year the program is drafted correctly so we do not have to face prosecutions in years to come. Let us try to help these people because they are damned good people and deserve that help. In conclusion, I extend a very warm invitation to all members of parliament and their families to come along on the Labour Day weekend-on 11, 12, 13 and 14 March-and enjoy the festival, the hospitality and the friendship of the people of Myrtleford, and to see for themselves the results of these people's hard work over many years and their contribution to Australia.

Speaker: Mr MARTYN EVANS
Title: PROHIBITION AMENDMENT BILL
text: -It is very good to see the degree of bipartisanship which is part of the flavour of debates of this kind. It has always been my experience in health debates revolving around the prohibition of tobacco advertising, to a greater or lesser degree, in the state parliament and now in the federal parliament that there is a significant degree of bipartisanship about these matters. There are certainly arguments at the margins about degree and about the extent of exemptions, for example. But with the exemption of one or two opposition spokesmen in the recent past-and I think that situation has now changed quite significantly-both sides of this House and both sides of politics in country agree that tobacco sponsorship, tobacco advertising and tobacco consumption generally are a serious threat to the health of Australians at large and, in particular, a serious threat-albeit a deferred one-to the health of young people. Those are some of the issues I would like to canvass in my contribution to this debate today. Any debate about smoking and tobacco consumption and the historical context must be considered over a very long period of time. I think the harsh reality is that history will judge Sir Walter Raleigh very sharply. I would not be surprised to find that he becomes known as one of the greatest mass murderers in history. In defence of his memory, I would have to say that, at the time, there was no way he could have known the consequences of his bringing tobacco to the Old World and starting the spread of that substance-that drug-throughout what we now know as Western society and, increasingly, to developing countries. I think it is very important to see just what the consequences of his actions will be. Recent studies have shown and latest estimates indicate that by the year 2025 cigarettes will be killing 10 million people a year. It is not too far off-some 30 years from nowthat 10 million people a year around the world will die from smoking. That eclipses anything which any other person involved in trying to kill human beings has ever achieved. I think that kind of tally is something which we have to take note of. The statistics come in thick and fast. I know many of my colleagues on both sides of the House have indicated in this debate just how terrible some of those statistics are. But if we look a few years into the future we will see this on a global basis, which is the only real way of doing it when looking at the impact of tobacco smoking, and realise that it will be the cause of death of some 10 million people a year around the world. That really puts this kind of debate in perspective. If we examine this at a more mundane and economic level, in both the United States and Australia, because they are the two countries for which more precise figures are available, this we can see that the cost in dollar terms-not in terms of people's lives but dollar termshas reached a staggering $US52 billion per year, which includes all the cost of things like fire insurance, damage and health related costs put together. In the United States, the economic cost of tobacco is in the order of $52 billion a year. This puts into some perspective the comments of the previous speaker about governments and their revenue raising requirements. I intend to say a bit more about that shortly. When we look at revenue from tobacco products, we have to take into account the very enormous costs to society and to governments at large of tobacco smoking. If we look at that $52 billion in more personal terms, we will see that it puts the cost of tobacco smoking at something like $8,000 per smoker per year. Of course, there are costs which go beyond the direct economic costs. Those people who smoke are likely to have 6.5 days greater absenteeism from work each year than a non-smoker. That has enormous productivity flow-on costs right throughout the economy, both private and public. We also have the impact of deaths from passive smoking-the environmental tobacco smoke question, which is far more uncertain and subject to much more debate these days. In the United States alone, the latest estimates indicate that 3,000 to 5,000 people die each year from environmental tobacco smoke. We can translate many of those figures into the Australian context and look at the impact of 20,000 deaths alone in Australia per year. When we translate those figures into a more personal measure that each of us in this House can relate to, we find that we are talking about something like two of our constituents per week dying from tobacco related illnesses. If we think of it in that context-that is, two constituents per week dying from tobacco related illnesses-we realise the real cost of smoking to Australia and to the families in our area and the way in which that impacts not only on their own personal lives--on income forgone for that family, lost opportunities and the loss of loved ones-but also on Australia, the dramatic personal cost to Australia and the economy as a whole. The reason for the legislation that we have before us today relates to recent High Court decisions and the need to ensure that this legislation remains viable and is not able to be attacked at a straightforward level by the tobacco companies. The changes we have seen in the High Court recently have meant that we have to be ever much more vigilant about the way in which our legislation is cast. Something which would have been quite clear and unchallengeable a while ago is now subject to challenge on some very interesting grounds. The recent political advertising case certainfew. ly brought out the interests which we must seek to protect in legislation of this kind, which, in my view, do not go to freedom of speech. The reality is that this is a debate about preventing ill health, about saving the lives of Australians, young and old, and is not a debate about political free speech. Nonetheless, I acknowledge that the High Court is capable of finding those issues in legislation of this kind. Therefore, it is essential in protecting that greater good that this parliament ensures the legislation, so far as possible, is beyond attack in the courts. It is very instructive to have a look at some of the words of the High Court in relation to those issues. The justices who looked at this matter-in fact, all six justices who were present on that case-held that freedom of political discourse was the subject of an implied constitutional protection but that this freedom was not absolute. Their Honours recognised that this freedom, although important, may be subject to more important competing interests such as national security, the administration of justice or other laws necessary in an ordered and democratic society. In order to determine which interests should prevail, obviously a balancing process must take place. The court indicated quite clearly that parliament was the organisation which should seek to find that balance in the first instance and that the role of the court would merely be a supervisory one where parliament had exceeded its authority. Justice Brennan in his decision stated: The balancing of the protection of other interests against the freedom to discuss governments and political matters is, under our Constitution, a matter for the Parliament to determine and for the Courts to supervise. The role of the court in judicially reviewing a law that is said to curtail the freedom unduly and thereby to exceed legislative power is supervisory. It declares whether a balance struck by the Parliament is within or without the range of legislative choice. In a society vigilant of its democratic rights and privileges, it might be expected that the occasions when the Parliament deliberately steps outside the range of legitimate choice would be It is also important to note the judgment of Chief Justice Mason where he says: ... only a compelling justification will warrantthe imposition of a burden on free communication by way of restriction and the restriction must be no more than is reasonably necessary to achieve the protection of the competing public interest which is invoked to justify the burden on communication. I think this legislation does just that. The kinds of facts which I and speakers on both sides of this House have discussed-in relation to the burden on the health of Australians and the vulnerability of young people in regard-more than justify the prohibitions which this act imposes and the further prohibitions sought to be imposed by these amendments. However, they do contain a number of exemptions designed to ensure that, where there is a legitimate right of free speech to exercised by tobacco companies, they are a position to do so and that the law does not necessarily burden or constrain which the High Court would find would impinge against the right of political free speech. This is not a US first amendment freedom as such; this is a right of speech which must be balanced against other interests in our society. In this case those interests overwhelming. They relate to the health of the nation and to public safety. No interest, from perhaps national security, could be more important for this parliament to defend. When we look at this legislation, it is important to take into account the reasons why we seek to prohibit advertising. It is instructive to look at the undertakings of the tobacco companies themselves. has been the most profitable company in the United States in recent years. Its profitability reaches a staggering level. In 1992 Philip Morris was the seventh largest industrial corporation in the US, with $US50 billion annual sales. However, when these corporations were ranked according to profit, in 1992 Philip Morris, with a profit of $US4.9 billion, more money than any other company in the United States, which reflects the fantastic ettes. level of profits which cigarette manufacturers enjoy. The product is very cheap to produce and, of course, can be sold at quite high prices. With very small increases in the price of the cigarettes, they are able to substantially increase their profit margins even further. But the fact that a company like Philip Morris should be able to tum in a profit of $US4.9 billion trading-as it does-almost exclusivelyon the health, ill-health and, indeed, the death of individuals in our society, is something which should make this House and this parliament take very strong notice of. I hope that it is an issue which would also weigh this very heavily on the justices of the High Court, were it to be required to judge this matter. The impact of tobacco advertising is quite significant, and we can follow its trends over recent years. Indeed, in 1925 the average consumption was of the order of 1,000 cigarbe ettes per adult per year, which translates into in one pack of 20 a week. That grew very steadily and the main trigger for that growth them in a way was World War I. Over the course of World War I, tobacco consumption went up 1Y2 times and then fell because of the Great Depression-thus reflecting the economic uncertainties of the timesbut then grew steadily again until World War are II started in 1940, at which point we were on 2,000 cigarettes per adult per year. However, apart by the end of World War II, we were up to nearly 3,500 cigarettes per adult per year. From that point onwards, it continued to grow until it plateaued in about 1960-65 at something over 4,000· cigarettes per adult per year-a very substantial growth from 1925 to 1965, from 1,000 to just over 4,000 cigarettes Philip Morris per adult per year. That growth was clearly driven by a couple of things: the rise of the mass consumer marketing society which that period reflected very substantially; and the increasing wealth in of ordinary people over that period, which was quite a significant factor. Also the contributions of World War I and World War II could not be understated in that context. made However, the increase also reflected the increasing power of addiction of those cigarOnce smokers start that habit, it is very hard to give it up. I have never tried myself, so I cannot comment on the reality of that. But those I know who have tried to give up smoking-the efforts of the Quit campaign, of medical practitioners and of smokers forced to resort to nicotine patches and the like-all testify to the difficulties involved. Consumption remained very high until about the mid-1970s when it began a downward spiral. As at 1990, we had dropped to just below 3,000 cigarettes per adult per year. These figures reflect a number of changes in society as well: the non-smokers rights movement which started back in 1975; the massive increases in federal and state taxes which took place during the 1980s; and the health warnings and the massive publicity given to the health risks associated with tobacco over that period, which resulted in a significant downturn in tobacco consumption. Looking at the impact of cigarette advertising, we see that tobacco companies, very wisely from their point of view, focus it quite clearly on young people. It is their intention to secure a market at a very young age, knowing that that will give them consumers for a very long time---consumers who will be quite insensitive to changes in price. If we do not ensure that young people are not caught by the tobacco habit at a very young age, we will never succeed in altering the health and smoking habits of older Australians. While we have had very significant prohibitions on tobacco advertising in this country for some time, there are very few effective case studies-although if you look at the way in which young people pick up particular brands of cigarettes in different states, which reflects the outcomes of different promotional campaigns in those states, you can see the effectiveness of tobacco advertising. One of the most striking examples of why we must vigilantly seek to maintain this ban is that of the Camel cigarette company in the United States. It is quite interesting to look the data from that case. The Camel cigarette advertising campaign clearly has children as its principal target group. In 1988, with Camel sales declining, RJR Nabisco launched a marketing campaign featuring Old Joe Camel-a smooth character, presumably modelled after someone like James Bond. In the adverts, Old Joe rides motorcycles, shoots pool and associates with attractive women while smoking Camel cigarettes. Three years into the campaign, surveys showed that 14 per cent of adults over the age of 18 identified Camel as the most advertised cigarette brand in the United States, whereas 29 percent--double the number--ofteenagers 12 to 17 years of age and a staggering 34 per cent of 12to 13-year-olds believed Camel was the most advertised brand. Even more striking is another survey which showed that 30 per cent of three-year-olds and over 80 per cent of six-year-olds are able to associate a picture of Old Joe Camel with a packet of cigarettes. Among six-year-olds, the same percentage associated the package of cigarettes with Old Joe Camel as were able to associate a picture of the Disney channel logo with Mickey Mouse. Those kinds of statistics indicate very clearly the pattern in advertising which has been adopted in the United States to target young people in particular. The fact that those as young as three and six years old are able to so clearly identify with the brand of a particular packet of cigarettes is a very frightening statistic indeed. The cigarette companies have continued to pursue those policies right throughout the world, and particularly in developing countries where they hope to develop further campaigns which will ensure that young people in those countries with substantially higher population bases are addicted to the product as well. The tobacco companies have never ceased to deny the risks associated with tobacco smoking in a way which I think is quite reprehensible. Indeed this has brought about a trend in the United States where the state of Florida has initiated very interesting legislation, which I understand is now being picked up by the United States Congress and which at may eventually have to be picked up here. Florida has adopted an amendment to its legislation which insists that cigarette makers can be sued by the state itself for the health costs of tobacco related illnesses. In the case of Florida, it is suing the tobacco companies for reimbursement of about $300 million a year in Medicaid expenses for smoking related illnesses. That legislation is through the Florida parliament, it has been enacted by the governor, and legal cases are already pending in Florida. It represents a very significant legislative change in the way in which these matters are administered. If we are to be serious about tobacco control and tobacco legislation, it is essential that we pursue the kinds of advertising regulations and restrictions which this act encompasses. I certainly commend to the House, and indeed at some future point no doubt to the courts, the benefits of this legislation to the Australian people. Debate (on motion by Mr Beazley) adjourned.
