Speaker: Mr TICKNER
Title: COMMITTEE ON NATIVE TITLE AND
text: Hughes-Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs) (10.56 a.m.)-I move: That Senate amendments Nos 1 to 3 made in place of request not pressed, and further amendments Nos 4 to 17,23 to 27, 31 to 33,35,41 to 4-, 45 to 48, 51 to 56, 63 and 65 (Group 1) be disagreed to. Thank you, Mr Speaker, for the opportunity to speak again on what the government believes is a historic piece of legislation. I want to begin by again putting on the record the government's motivation in bringing this legislation before the House. In 1992 the High Court of Australia brought down the historic Mabo decision. That decision changed for all time the position of i-digenous people in this country. It recogmsed that there were still some indigenous p-ople wh? could trace back their relationship wIth certam parts of land for time immemorial-long before non-indigenous Australians ever came to these shores. But, as we all now know, the extent of the existence of native title is finite and is, in the government's view going to be far more limited than was expected when the Mabo decision first came down. To his great credit and the credit of the nation, in the historic Redfern speech made in Redfern park in Sydney, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made it clear that the Mabo decision was to be a historic turning point. He made it clear that it was to be the basis of a new relationship between indigenous and nonindigenous Australians, and that it was going to make a very significant contribution to the reconciliation process. The government then put in train a series of consultations and negotiations, which went for an extended period. As a result of those negotiations, the government developed a three-stage response to the High Court decision in the Mabo case. The first stage was the Native Title Act. That 48, act will remain for all time as one of the great achievements of our federal Labor government. I believe that with the passage of time that legislation and the protection it gives to ' , native title will gain the full endorsementindeed, the unanimous support-of this parliament. Regrettably, it did not pass through the parliament with that unanimous support on the first occasion, but I am confident that the tide will tum and that, before the end of the decade, unanimous support will be forthcoming. The second stage of the government's response is the Land Fund and Indigenous Land Corporation (ATSIC Amendment) Bill 1994. I will tum in detail to that in a moment. That bill has been the subject of considerable debate both inside and outside the parliament. The third stage response has been referred to as the social justice package. That offers both the coalition and the government an opportunity to start afresh. It offers us the opportunity to look at the reports that come from the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, of which the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent) is a member. It enables us to look at the report coming in the month ahead from ATSIC and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner. Those reports will raise challenging i-s.ues for both the government and the oppoSItIOn. Since the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) is in the chamber, I want to say to him and the shadow minister, with all the conviction and sincerity I can muster, that the government will be seeking the greatest degree of cross-party support for the way in which we deal with that social justice package. It will raise some very challenging and difficult issues, but I am confident that, if allow a proper process of consultation and discussion of these issues, we will be able to achieve a large measure of cross-party support. Despite what the Leader of the Opposition may occasionally think of me-and the shadow minister for health, the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), would confirm this to him-I come to this portfolio with a genuine commitment to achieve cross-party cooperation. I hope that we can move back to a far greater degree of cross-party cooperation, if it is at all achievable. The amendments the government is not supporting have been referred to by Senator Evans as the seven deadly sins, and we are not supporting the other amendments for good reason. May I take a bit of the House's time to refer in a measured and considered way to our reasons for not supporting the amendments. The government will be supporting a very large number of amendments and, even as late as yesterday, Senator Evans was prepared to accept another amendment, which was picked up with the motions that were moved this morning. This matter came on for debate in the Senate yesterday. My good friend Senator Teague missed the original vote and, as a further demonstration of the government's bona fides, the matter was recommitted. One of the amendments concerns the requirement that priority of land allocation be given to the most disadvantaged in relation to their access to land or to those who are unable to gain substantive title to land. A number of amendments are opposed by the government because we believe they are contrary to the fundamental principles of the bill. For very considered reasons, other amendments are opposed because the government believes that they would make the bill unworkable-and this is one of the amendments the government considers would have that effect. I pose the question as to what the definition of access might be. Is it to be defined in some physical sense? In some states and the Northern Territory, guaranteed access to pastoral we leases exists in legislation. Can that be compared with the rights conferred by full ownership? To the Aboriginal people in New South Wales, I pose the question: is the word 'access' to be defined in some structural sense-that is, access to land acquisition programs or possession of legislative rights to claim land, regardless of whether the claim would be successful? If that were the interpretation adopted, Aboriginal people in New South Wales would go to the absolute bottom of the queue. There is a further difficulty in relation to people who may be unable to gain substantive title to land. In relation to people who have made a native title or other claim to land which they ultimately may not be able to prove, the question arises as to how they fit into this amendment. There is a great deal of uncertainty which would lead to great difficulties in the operation of the fund. Of further concern is the matter of assessing priority in the allocation of land fund moneys. We believe that should be left to the Indigenous Land Corporation board, which in the absence of legislative prescription will be able to take into account the diversity of the needs of indigenous people. I tum now to the issue of grants to individuals and trustees. I ask honourable members to think very seriously about this matter. This amendment was supported by the coalition and by the Greens. Again, we ask the coalition to think very seriously about it. We think it amounts to a radical-I use that word advisedly-and adverse change in relation to Commonwealth grants to indigenous people for the purchase of land. If the parliament carried the opposition's view, it would be the first time in the entire history of Commonwealth legislative action in respect of indigenous people since the 1967 referendum that grants would be made to individual people. We do not think that is good policy. It is certainly not the policy of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. The coalition's stated rationale for the amendment is that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people should be treated like other Australians who are not required to incorporate in order to have title to land. At first blush, that argument has some substance. However, there is a counterargument which we believe ought to prevail; that is, other Australians do not have access to the land fund. This is a special case of positive discrione mination designed to address past injustice. The land fund provides an avenue for indigenous people in addition, to that which is available to other Australians. No-one on this side of the parliament has ever suggested that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people should not be free to pursue ordinary means of acquiring land. Please do not suggest or think that we suggest everything for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in Australia must be communal. One of my great hopes, which I am sure is shared by the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) and the honourable member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell), is to see an increasing number of entrepreneurial individual Aboriginal peopleand I think we are already seeing thismaking a success of investment, land ownership and business.· But that is not the purpose of this fund. Again, that is one of the reasons why we do not support the amendment. The Senate committee established to look into the matter purported to assert that individual ownership was traditionally accepted in some indigenous communities. The committee referred to evidence given by Mr Donald Whaleboat, a Torres Strait Islander. When I looked closely at the evidence given, I found that the Torres Strait Islander was not asserting principles of individual ownership but principles of family ownership. Of course, that is a characteristic of indigenous land ownership in the Torres Strait. In fact, it was precisely the kind of communal or family ownership that was recognised in the Mabo decision itself. I turn to the amendment relating to health, education, social and cultural needs. There has perhaps been more public debate on this amendment than any other. The government would agree, as I certainly do, that very much of the debate has been symbolic. The questions we pose are: 'What is the amendment intended to specify? How will the needs be assessed? How will we quantify the difference that the land acquisition will make?' Either the needs must be assessed and the benefits quantified-in which case it undermines the whole philosophy behind the bill, which is of returning the bill-or, if that is not what is meant, it is effectively windowdressing. At this time it is important to make the point that the government believes passionately that one of the greatest social justice issues confronting this country is Aboriginal health. We have already had some debates in this chamber about that matter, and I am sure that we will have a lot more.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: COMMITTEE ON NATIVE TITLE AND
text: We will.

Speaker: Mr TICKNER
Title: COMMITTEE ON NATIVE TITLE AND
text: I am glad that the Leader of the Opposition joins in that. Can I say to him that I think he will have to judge the government on what it does on this issue. I ask the House and the people of Australia to have regard to the Prime Minister's recent speech at Hopevale in the electorate of Leichhardt where he made the point that the government had moved in respect of native title to establish the land fund and the next priority was clearly that of health. There is much work to be done on that. Again, I would hope that, whilst we might debate the best means of addressing the issues, we ought to, on this issue, strive for our future directions with the greatest degree of cross-party cooperation on what might be done. Again I turn to a good basis for doing that, and that is the unanimous report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs called Rhetoric or reality. I am getting some signals that suggest that it is in the interest of the parliament that we move more expeditiously. I do not think we have ever been so eager to accommodate each other as on this occasion, but perhaps that is not a bad thing. I turn to the amendments that relate to the Indigenous Land Corporation pursuing a policy of not requiring any consent for the disposal of land. Of all the issues that are likely to arouse enormous public opposition and public concern in the wider Australian community, it has to be this one. I have to say frankly that the government thinks it very bad public policy that we would allocate funds, perhaps, to an individual person and by law of the parliament effectively give that person a blank cheque authority to be able to dispose of the land the very next day. I pose a challenge for the coalition. I am not aware of any area in any portfolio responsibility in the Commonwealth where there has been such a policy. It has never been coalition policy before. Mr Tim Fischer-EMDG-xport market well in practice. development grants.

Speaker: Mr TICKNER
Title: COMMITTEE ON NATIVE TITLE AND
text: Interest in land, I pose to the Leader of the National Party? It has never been coalition policy and it has never been government policy to allow that kind of effective abdication-and I think a rather cavalier abdication---of our responsibility as a parliament to stand up for important princiCourt ples of public accountability. The government clearly cannot support that amendment. I draw the coalition's attention that the Aboriginal Development Commission legislation, passed by a coalition government-I think Fred Chaney was the minister there, although I may be wrong-contains a provision prohibiting the disposal of land in the way that the government is advocating this bill. Section 21(3) of the ATSIC Act makes it clear that no disposal of land will permitted in relation to A TSIC funding without the consent of the commission. I put on the public record that the ATSIC legislation has now enjoyed the unanimous support of the parliament. That is very welcome. The question I pose is: why would we want to ditch what has been agreed to be a fundamental principle of public accountability? There are other amendments that I could refer to. Honourable members would apprecithe ate that it is rather difficult for me when on my feet to appreciate the tenor of what the opposition might be about to do. I think I have anticipated the opposition correctly-at least I hope so. I want to conclude my remarks by saying a number of things briefly about this legislation from a government perspective. This proposal to establish a land fund is something that has been an objective of mine for all the time that I have been in the parliament because I think it is very important that the nation address the dispossessed position of Aboriginal Australians. It is legislation that comes forward with all the hallmarks of good legislation. We have principles of public accountability enshrined, and we believe that we have all the necessary checks and balances and safeguards to make the legislation work Above all else, the government sees this as the historic second stage response to the High Court decision in the Mabo case, and I want to take this opportunity to place on record the magnificent role that the Prime Minister has played in realising what had to be done to deliver social justice in response to that High decision. This is the second stage of the government's response. The third stage will be the social justice package. Before that, in relation to the budget, obviously health will to the fact have a high priority. Mr Speaker, this is further reason why we on this side are very proud to be members of the Australian Labor Party. I would urge the coalition to think again in relation to its past in opposition to the government's proposals and to have this legislation passed through today be with the unanimous support of this chamber and that of the Senate to achieve the unanimous passage through the Australian parliament that it deserves.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: COMMITTEE ON NATIVE TITLE AND
text: Mr Speaker, I enter this debate on the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994 for the opposition to say a few words as to our general approach to the whole question of the government's land fund legislation. Let me start by saying that we in coalition believe very strongly that the I a'll amendments that were inserted into the original land fund bill were justified amendments. They would, if adopted by the national parliament, deliver a better land fund, a fairer land fund and a land fund that recognised the rights of individuals as distinct from the rights of groups and corporations. I also want to take the opportunity to acknowledge particularly the contribution made by my Senate colleagues Senator Ian Campbell and Senator Chris Ellison. Over a period of months, they worked extremely effectively in order to insert these amendments into the legislation. Leaving aside any detailed explanation of the constitutional technicalities and the times from which deadlocked provisions begin to operate, quite obviously we have reached a stage where there is a deadlock between the two houses of parliament. The Senate wants a piece of legislation that it believes, and I believe, is superior to that wanted by the government and, clearly, by the House of Representatives. If that deadlock were to continue, the people who would suffer most would be the people the legislation is intended to benefit. For those reasons, the coalition has decided that, although on the motion of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) it will maintain support for the Senate's amendments, next week, when the second piece of legislation introduced by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is presented, it will not vote against the passage of that legislation in either the House of Representatives or the Senate. We do that on a number of strict understandings that I want to make clear from the very beginning. The first of those is that on the election of a coalition government, which will inevitably occur whenever the election is held, we will vote to amend the land fund legislation to bring it into line with what was resolved by the Senate. I want to make that very clear: we will amend the legislation to bring it into line with what was resolved by the Senate. It seems to us that that is the most intelligent way of handling this issue. The consequence of that will be that the Aboriginal community will not be denied the benefit of the land fund provisions but, equally, the inadequacies of that legislation will be excised upon a change of government. The second set of circumstances in which I make these remarks on behalf of the coalition is to say something generally about our approach to Aboriginal affairs. There is an enormous amount of rhetoric about Aboriginal affairs. There is an enormous amount of breast beating. There is an enormous amount of-how should one put it?-preciousness when it comes to possession of moral authority and compassion. In relation to Aboriginal affairs, no side of politics in Australia has a mortgage on compassion. There are many men and women of goodwill on both sides of the parliament who have been very concerned about the plight of Australia's indigenous people for a very long time. The fair-minded amongst those opposite will acknowledge, going back over the years, the contribution of many people on our side of politics to a sensitive understanding of the difficulties faced by the Aboriginal people. It is not an easy issue. I detect in the Australian community a general desire to see the condition and the state of Australia's indigenous people improved. There is a recognition by most Australians that, as a group of people, Aborigines are clearly the most disadvantaged within our national community. There is also within the Australian community a growing impatience with what seems to it to be the expenditure of hundreds of millions of dollars, with precious little advancement and, in some cases, actual regression. Whatever the government may say, whatever the minister may say and whatever the Prime Minister may say, the reality is that, after 12 years of government and the expenditure of hundreds of millions of additional dollars, the condition of Aboriginal health is worse than what it was when you came to power, in many crucial respects. That is the fact. If we are to have an intelligent debate about Aboriginal affairs, it ought to focus on issues like that and not be distracted as to who is taking the most morally superior position when it comes to responses to Mabo or responses to the land fund. We can talk for days, for weeks, indeed months, about that and if, as a consequence, the most wretched amongst our number are not advanced or not promotedMr Dodd interjecting

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: COMMITTEE ON NATIVE TITLE AND
text: We hear lots of speeches about how every so often those who represent the people of Australia in this building ought to look beyond the short-term political point or the political advantage. We have done that. We are acknowledging that, if the deadlock continues, you opposite will not suffer and we over here will not suffer; but the people the land fund is meant to develop will suffer. We are not going to be a party to that. We are, therefore, going to take the course of action that I have indicated. I want to make it clear to those who sit opposite that they do not have a mortgage on compassion. As my colleague the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), the shadow minister for health, said yesterday, it is not a problem that additional dollars alone can solve although, obviously, financial provision is tremendously important. It goes to a lot of other things as well. There is an obligation on all of us to address those other things, but addressing those other things has to occur within a number of important guidelines and understandings. One of those guidelines and understandings so far as the coalition is concerned now, and will always be so far as the Liberal and National parties are concerned, is that Aboriginal affairs has to be addressed within the concept of a single, undivided nation of which all Australians, whether indigenous Australians or other Australians, are treated equally, governed by a common set of laws to which all of us are equally accountable and governed by a number of common values and common principles as Australian citizens. be part of the policy of the Liberal and National parties to see the development of Aboriginal affairs policy within the concept of the tribalisation or fragmentation of this nation. We are one people and one nation, with one future, and one common obligation to treat each of us with dignity and respect. I hope that the debate on Aboriginal affairs from now on will focus on policies and measures that improve the dignity, the independence, the lifestyle, the health, the education, the employment prospects and the family stability of Australia's Aborigines. It ought not to be distracted by arguments as to who is more compassionate. It ought not to be distracted by challengeable concepts of intergenerational guilt. Of course injustices were done to the original people, but those injustices were not committed by current generations of Australians and, so far as I am concerned, I am not going to be a party to the gUilt industry, but I am going to be a party toMr Tickner interjecting

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: COMMITTEE ON NATIVE TITLE AND
text: I am glad the minister says he is not a party to the gUilt industry. I am delighted to hear that, and I hope his acknowledgment is recorded. What this parliament has to do is to embrace common sense, contemporary policies to improve the conditions of Aborigines-to improve their self-respect, their independence and their self reliance. Those policies have to be developed not within the context of notions of intergenerational guilt and not within the context of the fragmentation of this country but within the context of the unity of this country under a common set of Australian values and a common body of law. Finally, what the coalition has decided to do on this legislation is against a background of press comment about a double dissolution. I would love to have an election at the present time, and all of my colleagues over here would love to have an election at the present time. The only people who do not want to have an election at the present time are those who sit opposite. So this decision taken by the coalition has nothing at all to do with question of the timing of elections. We would love It will never to have an election. If the Prime Minister wants to have an election on this or indeed any other issue he only has to hop in that flagless white car of his and go out to Yarralumla and advise the Governor General to grant him a double dissolution. This decision has absolutely nothing to do with that. This decision has been taken by us because we believe that, given that there is a clear deadlock between the two houses of parliament, the people who will suffer from that deadlock will be the Aboriginal community of Australia. In those circumstances, the sensible, proper thing to do, having regard to the interests of the Aboriginal community of Australia, is to do what the coalition has resolved to do. We will maintain, by voting against the minister's motion, a demonstration of support for the Senate amendments. But when the bill introduced by the Prime Minister comes on for debate next week, we will not vote against that legislation in either the House of Representatives or the Senate. Upon the election a Howard-Fischer government, whenever that occurs, we will act to amend the land fund legislation to bring it into line with what been passed by the Senate. In that fashion, not only serve the interests of the Aboriginal community but we also produce better legislawhat tion and, most importantly, we return debate on Aboriginal affairs to areas of government accountability where it ought to be. We will also return the general political and economic debate of this community to the other failings of the government and all the other areas of government accountability. If any members opposite imagine that the behaviour of the Prime Minister and the government over the past few days on this issue has been some kind of clever political tactic, I think they are sadly wrong. We will get the debate back to where you are weakest and, in the process, we will look after interests of the Aboriginal community.

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Title: COMMITTEE ON NATIVE TITLE AND
text: Northern TerritoryEvans Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training) (11.28 ty. a.m.)-I am pleased that the opposition has at last seen the importance of passing this piece of legislation, however disingenuous that support might be. To hear what the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has said this morning must confirm in everyone's mind how disingenuous the opposition is in relation to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander we affairs-without question. What these people have done today is to indicate to the parliament, to the people Australia, that they are prepared to acceptthe proposals put forward by the government in the context of the land fund bill on the basis that when and if-in the very unlikely event-they be elected to government they will immediately move to amend the legislation in accordance with the principles of the amendments passed by the Senate. There, in its entirety, is the message to the Australian community. These people are absolutely disingenuous. What is also interesting is that whilst the of Leader of the Opposition has spoken about the need for a cohesive approach to this particular issue, an issue on which we join has him-we would say there is a need for a we cohesive approach, that we should have a national bipartisan approach to these issueshe has demonstrated in his contribution is an absolute and fundamental misunderstanding about the thrust of the land fund bill. What he has done by supporting the proposals which have come from the Senate is to indicate absolutely that he has no idea about the importance of land and its relationship to Aboriginal people. The Leader of the Opposition has entirely ignored the evidence put forward on any number of occasions by royal commissioners, Aboriginal leadership and politicians. The government has indicated in the Senate that so clearly is it committed to the idea of bipartithe sanship that it accepted 29 amendments proposed in that other place. But it has, quite rightly, chosen to reject what Senator Gareth has called the seven deadly sins. It was the opposition leader's support of the seven deadly sins that should have us concerned and should be of concern to the whole communiI want to refer to those points but before I do I want to make a general observation about the proposals in the opposition leader's speech on the One Nation concept-the idea that we are all governed by a common law. We all understand that; no-one questions it. But what are arguing is that we need to deal specially and differently in some cases with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. They need to be given special recognition in law as of a result of past injustices about which he spoke. We acknowledged their alienation from their land base by passing the Mabo legislation and, prior to that, the land rights legislapeople. tion in the Northern Territory; and we are looking at this land fund bill and the social justice package. We acknowledge the need to give Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people special treatment. We acknowledge the need to address special needs. We acknowledge the need to address the principles in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander law. That is the difference. The relationship with land is integral and key to that. The Leader of the Opposition has also said the opposition is not about a guilt trip. No-one is; but he refers to the injustices of the past without acknowledging the injustices of the present. That is another key failing of his contribution and of the proposals which have been put by the opposition. He has a fundamental lack of understanding about the injustices to which Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are subjected in this nation today. The Leader of the Opposition has said he looks forward to a very good debate-and no doubt a volatile debate at times-about Aboriginal health and housing issues. He says that should be the primary debate. Let me just point out to him that, as we know, the government has already rejected the amendments in the Senate which refer to tying the proposals put forward in this legislation to the questions of disadvantage and health and housing. I will go to comments by a member of the Liberal Party, a person who I understand is up for preselection for the Liberal Party, Brendan Nelson. Dr Nelson, along with purports Barbara Flick, has published a document Aboriginal entitled Land, Rights, Laws: Issues of Native Title. In it, they talk about rights and entitlemunity-by ments. They have acknowledged the primacy of Aboriginal interest in land and the need to address that land issue quite separately but conjunction with issues to deal with health and housing. They understand that, unless address this land issue, the possibility of getting a fruitful outcome in health and education is more difficult. That goes statements which have been made by various Aboriginal leaders over at least the history Australia's occupation by non-Aboriginal When I look at the contribution which the opposition leader has made. I become alarmed that he has demonstrated no understanding of these things. If we are going to express bipartisan support, we must at least agree on the fundamentals. It is difficult to understand what fundamental agreements we might have, if we have a basic disagreement about the importance of land to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and the way it ought to be dealt with. In talking about how land should be dealt with, I note that the opposition has said that it should be made available to individuals and trustees. I wonder why the opposition has not had the wisdom to read what the various reports, which have been presented to government over the last 20 years by learned people in the form of royal commissions-the Woodward commission, the Seaman inquiry for the Western Australian government-have said about the nature of land, land ownership and title. What all of them have done is reject the notion that land should be made available to an individual. In fact, they have said-as they have committed themselves to understanding the nature of Aboriginal association with land-that land ownership must be inalienable; it should not be sold; it should not be dealt with in a way in which nonAboriginal people deal with land. Land is fundamental to Aboriginal spirituality, yet it is something which the opposition Dr will not understand. The opposition still to be dealing with the interests of and Torres Strait Islander people--indeed the interests of the Australian comgoing down this path. It says that people should be able to deal with this landwhich, after all, is recognition of their spiriin tual attachment-as if they were real estate agents. They are not real estate agents. I have we lived and worked with Aboriginal people for many years and I have not heard one Aboriginal person put this view. We have had the to land rights act operating in the Northern Territory since 1976-inalienable freehold of title. Not one Aboriginal person that I have spoken to in the Northern Territory has put the view that they want individual ownership. Then we have the position with regard to ATSIC. It is very important that we understand this. What the opposition is doing by taking the approach that it has taken thus and by adopting the approach that the Leader of the Opposition has put forward this morning-that, in the unlikely event it were to get power, it would turn over this legislation-is absolutely pulling the rug from underneath any semblance of recognition of ATSIC and the authority it might have in the Aboriginal and Torres Straight Islander community. We should be very aware of the position of ATSIC. The ATSIC commissioners have made their position abundantly clear on numerous occasions. Lois O'Donoghue and Charlie Perkins have, at various times

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: COMMITTEE ON NATIVE TITLE AND
text: Ha, hal

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Title: COMMITTEE ON NATIVE TITLE AND
text: You laugh. What are you laughing at? That absolutely ignores the reality of what A TSIC does. It absolutely ignores the structures of ATSIC. I was at a regional council meeting of ATSIC last week in the Northern Territory. There was a group of representatives from across the top end of the Northern Territory, each one of them representing a view of their communities. They were a representative group. You might not like it, but they were representative. The fact is that ATSIC is representative. You don't like it, but it is. What you ought to is acknowledge that and say that they do represent and speak on behalf of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. There is no point taking this argument to the point of saying that because there are some administrative difficulties with ATSIC-and there may well be-you throw the baby out with the bathwater, which is what you have done. You do not acknowledge at all the role of the leadership in ATSIC as representing the general interests of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities across Australia. The opposition should understand what it is doing. Not only are you disparaging this land fund bill; you are also disparaging the reprewhich sentative nature of ATSIC, the ATSIC commissioners and the prestige with which they are held in the Aboriginal community. This is what you are doing. We have the shadow spokesperson basically saying that ATSIC leadership does not consult and does not represent Aboriginal people. Is that not what far you are saying? The ATSIC leadership has made it clear where they stand on the land fund bill. They have said to the government that they want this bill, not your bill, and you should support it. But what you are saying is that if you get into government you· will totally undermine the basis of this legislation. How disingenuous are you? The opposition has now felt the blowtorch to the belly and caved in. That is what this is about. As Senator Gareth Evans said last night, we have now achieved the result we wanted, because our primary objective was to get the land fund bill through. You would not have supported this land fund bill if you did not think there was going to be a double dissolution. That is very clear. The opposition leader almost said as much this morning. I want to finish my contribution by saying to the House that this is a very important day for the Australian community. We have got the opposition falling to pieces, falling away, in terms of its attitude to the land fund bill in this parliament. But it is saying to the Australian community that, if and when it is elected, it will change this bill.to reflect the hideous prospect which was proposed by the do Senate. The only reason that they have come in here today to give in, if you like, is not, as the Leader of the Opposition says, the interests of Aboriginal and Tories Strait Islander people; it is as a result of self-interest. That needs to be properly understood. Nevertheless, self-interest is a legitimate interest and we accept the support of the opposition on this piece of legislation.

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Title: COMMITTEE ON NATIVE TITLE AND
text: I rise in support of the very statesmanlike comments made by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) with regard to this measure. I want to point out at the outset that we could have done better than have the comments the member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) has just made. He ignores, for example, the contribution of the New South Wales Land Council to this particular debate, which was strongly at variance with the view put by A TSIC. So there is a diversity of opinion amongst Aboriginals with regard to Labor's land fund legislation. Mr Dodd interjecting

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Title: COMMITTEE ON NATIVE TITLE AND
text: You might just spend a bit of time working on the problems of Kowanyama in your electorate and explain to them how the legislation before the House this day is going to lift equality of opportunity for education and the health and housing circumstances of the people of Kowanyama. Have you been to Kowanyama in the electorate of Leichhardt? Mr Dodd-Of course I have.

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Title: COMMITTEE ON NATIVE TITLE AND
text: I am pleased to see that you might have been there. It is a pity that you have not tried to rectify some of the tremendous problems that exist in that particular community. We are considering this legislation on the eve of another major ruling by the full bench of the High Court of Australia in relation to Mabo. I think in November the High Court finally took oral evidence, and some additional evidence was given after that. I managed to sit in for some of the full bench hearings here in Canberra on the Western Australian legislation and, inter alia, the federal Mabo legislation. The High Court is about to revisit the Mabo issue for the first time since its original decision. I point out to the House that that may well have ramifications for the core Mabo issues. It may necessitate another Mabo bill of one kind or another coming forward from the government. However, that remains to be seen and I am certainly not categorical about that. What I place on the public record is that, as we consider all the ramifications of the Mabo issue with regard to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and their health, education and housing circumstances, we need to be conscious of not only the parliamentary deliberation but also the fact that the High Court is about to revisit this issue. I understand that there will be a further ruling sometime between now and the end of April, at the latest. The second point is that in government we will review the core aspects of Labor's land funding apparatus for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I want to make it very clear that it would be part of our proper decision to relate the legislation to members of Aboriginal communities in very diverse circumstances. I quote in part from the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Land Fund Bill: A corporation is not an appropriate vehicle for the managementof modern [Aboriginal] communities. It is another imposed regime ... That evidence was taken from Rosemary O'Grady, the spokesperson of the Kamali people. Mr Tickner-She's a non-Aboriginal lawyer.

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Title: COMMITTEE ON NATIVE TITLE AND
text: But you will concede she was representing the Kamali people. I think that we ought to maintain a degree of reasonable standards associated with this debate, and I have always done so. In that context, when we review this legislation in government we will look forward, hopefully, to the support of the Australian Democrats and the Greens (WA). Hopefully, better still, the votes will be such that we will have a working majority in both houses of parliament so that we can get this right in the interests of Aboriginal people, in the interests of Australia as a nation as a whole. I praise the members of the committee and the senators who worked hard on this issue across the board. The committee was chaired by Senator Ian Campbell. In addition to the senators who were members of the committee, a senator for the Northern Territory, Senator Grant Tambling, and others certainly put in a huge amount of effort to bring forward responsible, reasonable amendments which have enjoyed a degree of support. I do not say more than that. I say that those amendments enjoyed a degree of support in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait community. Once in government, we will pursue those amendments and, indeed, will this day vote one more time for them in the deliberations of the House on this measure. On the legal side, it is worthy of note by members of the public and others that this bill is back before the House this morning because of section 57 of the constitution, which states: If the House of Representatives passes any proposed law, and the Senate rejects or fails to pass it, or passes it with amendments to which the House of Representatives will not agree ... It goes on from that point. Ultimately, late yesterday, the Senate passed the government's original land fund bill. The government construes that it was so amended that it did not constitute a passage of the government's original measure. But that has to be then tested on the floor of the House of Representatives today in accordance with section 57 of the constitution. If we had taken a view otherwise, it might be said for the record that, in broad terms, the trigger mechanism would have commenced from this day. But we do have the other complexity of the government arguing that the 1951 convention applied. The government lost that argument-in fact, Minister Evans ran up the white flag on that particular argument last night when he conceded he was wrong in saying that the trigger started back on 28 November. There was a very good reason for saying that. That 1951 convention involved a bill that was deadlocked between the House of Representatives and the Senate and was resubmitted after a three-month period. On the second time around, the Senate referred that particular banking legislation to a committee. At that time, Governor General MCKell construed that as a failure to pass on the second time around and the double dissolution then applied. On this occasion, the Senate is yet to deal with this legislation a second time around. For the benefit of clarification, that ought to be placed very clearly on the record of proceedings here today. In many ways this is a very unsatisfactory circumstance. As we speak here today there is a degree of agony, a degree of absolute unacceptability with regard to the actual conditions that exist across Cape York, western New South Wales and the Northern Territory. I am pleased that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has come into the House because he went to Cape York, I think, last weekend and perhaps saw first-hand some of those conditions. But I am sorry that the Prime Minister did not go to Kowanyama and see the conditions there. It takes a quantum leap of imagination to think that this particular measure will, within a short period of time, greatly improve the health, housing and educational circumstances of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders right across Australia. At the end of the day, that is what members on both sides of the House should be about, as those are the real issues of concern. The coalition has taken a very responsible position throughout the course of this debate for reasons that have been well stated by the Leader of the Opposition and, shortly, will be again by the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, the member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus). At the end of the day, we will be quite properly reviewing this in government.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Title: COMMITTEE ON NATIVE TITLE AND
text: When the government introduced the response to the High Court decision in relation to Mabo, it introduced a bill for an act to give meaning to the notion that there was a basis in the common law of Australia arising from Aboriginal custom and tradition to accept that there was a title available to those who maintain a traditional connection with the land, and to establish who was entitled to that land, how it would be allocated, how it would be decided and what those rights might be. It was thus a historic piece of property in cultural law. At the time of its introduction the government made clear that though this established in law a very great principle it would apply to those people who were still able to establish a traditional connection with the land and it would not apply to those who had formerly been dispossessed. Hence we said in the response to the High Court decision, to make clear the government's commitment to justice for Aboriginal people, that we would also introduce a land fund bill that would give Aboriginal people a capacity to buy land, particularly in areas where title may have been extinguished, where there had been a grant of interest for a short period-a pastoral lease or something as we saw recently in events alluded to in the remarks by Justice French. In those circumstances Aboriginal people could actually buy land and they would have a secure title to it. It was and remains a central matter in the dispensing of justice to Aboriginal people. The government was determined to get the Mabo bill, the native title bill, through. We stood our ground against intransigence in the Senate, we wore the admonition of the then Leader of the Opposition that it was a day of shame, we withstood the attenuated pressures of the opportunism of the coalition parties in the Senate, and during that period the Western Australian Greens, and said that we would campaign for this, in the country if necessary, were there a failure to pass it. Our determinawith tion to get our way, our way being justice for Aboriginal people, paid off for them when the bill was passed at the end of 1993. In accordance with the commitment we made we then said we would introduce an Aboriginal land fund bill, and we did this. According to our commitment we proposed that bill to the House of Representatives, and then it went to the Senate in September of last ual year. From September until yesterday and today the Senate dallied with the bill, behaved proposals opportunistically towards it, sought to under- though mine the central tenets of it, and then intro- capacity duced a long, drawn-out process supposedly of consultation which only revealed what a sham process the Senate had embarked upon under the stewardship of the Liberal and National parties and the Western Australian Greens. . Yesterday, Mr Speaker, the Senate passed the bill, and it passed it with the amendments whiCh the government objected to. Those amendments were to give priority now to those Aboriginal people who suffer the most disadvantage-as though, of course, there it back here. could be any secure test of the relative disadvantage of people or the relative dispossession. If one is dispossessed, one is dispossessed. The notion that the courts would then be asked to make judgments about these things was, of course, simply only a device and a sleight of hand. The second problem with it was that they wanted to see a reference to grants to individuals and trustees being made possible, encompassing the whole notion of the traditional connection of Aboriginal communities with the land, and the protection of that land in the hands of communities being put asunder. The third problem was that another requirement, that grants of interest in land have regard to health, housing and so on, meant that the character of the bill changed from being a land fund bill to an appropriation bill that was interested in health, housing and other things. That completely denied the bill its integrity in terms of dealing with land. The fourth problem was that they required the ILC, before acquiring land, to consult those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who had traditional or historic links to the land in question. The device there was that, without any resolution of some of these issues, the body itself would not be able to conduct its affairs in an executive way. It discusses the removal of the ILC power to control effectively the disposal of land; in other words, it deals with the right of individpeople to hold the land and actually dispose of it. It also referred to a group of relating to regional strategies, as they should in some way impair the of the fund to actually do what we require of it. This week the opposition parties had every chance to make a decision in favour of Aboriginal people without these devices, tricks and sleights of hand, and after this attenuated period, and send the legislation back with integrity to the House of Representatives for passage. They did not do this. They had the chance to decide on issues of justice. They denied themselves the chance, they denied Aboriginal people the chance, and they sent The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) today made it very clear that, were he to be the Prime Minister of this country, the coalition would seek to again run these amendmentsamendments which would tear the hell out of the bill. It is again said with insincerity towards the lot of Aboriginal people and that which is required for them. The government will today decide how to present the bill to the House-a bill which the Leader of the Opposition now says he will agree to have passed in the Senate. We will present a bill that will reflect the integrity the bill first proposed to the House of Representatives and the Senate.

Speaker: Mrs GALLUS
Title: COMMITTEE ON NATIVE TITLE AND
text: Hindmarsh) (12.05 p.m.)I am sorry that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is leaving. Never before have I been so disappointed with a Prime Minister of this country carrying on in such a way. He is totally and utterly incapable of getting out of the gutter. Those opposite with grinning faces should really look at what they have put up as the Prime Minister of this country. He cannot under any circumstances get out of the slime or the gutter and miss an opportunity to play politics. He made a political speech in Redfern about how much he cared for Aboriginal people. Ever since then, he has been playing Aboriginal affairs as a political football. He has done nothing else. The Prime Minister had an opportunity today to come into the House, as did our Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), and say, 'This is what we are going to do. Let's address the issues that are really hurting people out there. Let's get behind those Aboriginal people who are dying. Let's look at .the serious problems. Let's get this over and out of the way.' What happened? He came into this House and made the most feeble political points that he could make. He could not resist doing that. There is not one inch of statesman in your Prime Minister. He comes from the gutter, and he is determined to stay in the gutter. Let us look at some of the comments of the Prime Minister. He seemed to be a little confused in relation to which bill he was talking about. I am not surprised at that, considering the number of bills running around at the moment. Let me make this clear: we will not be voting for the A TSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994; we will be voting in support of the amendments moved by the Senate. We are doing this because we do not want Aboriginal affairs to become a total political football and we do not want bills to be going backwards and forwards. It is time to start addressing the most important issues. Let us look at some of the issues we have brought up in the Senateissues which the Prime Minister believes have 'gutted' and 'undermined' the bill. He referred to the Senate committee 'dallying' in relation to this bill. The committee travelled 12,000 kilometres and listened to 224 people. What did the Prime Minister do? He rushed off to one community. When the second bill is brought down next week, it is. with great regret that we will put it through without the amendments asked for by members of the Aboriginal community at large. They have said, 'The government did not consult.' I draw the attention of the House to words of the minister when he introduced the original bill. He said, 'We have consulted extensively, more extensively than ever before on this bill.' What did we find when we went around the country? Aboriginal group after Aboriginal group said, 'We were not consulted. This government does not reflect our community; it reflects the community over there.' Aboriginal people are not homogeneous. There are different Aboriginal communities around Australia, and they were excluded by this government from participating in this bill. Mr Ronaldson-They were not consulted?

Speaker: Mrs GALLUS
Title: COMMITTEE ON NATIVE TITLE AND
text: They wer,e not consulted. When they wrote to the government asking for consultation, they were sent the completed bill. This government failed to consult. We consulted with Aboriginal people, and the government did not. I turn to our amendments. Those opposite are obviously not interested in what I have to say. I will continue my remarks for the benefit of those in the gallery who perhaps have a genuine interest in Aboriginal affairs, unlike government members, who have an interest in disruption and in playing political football. I turn to some of the amendments that we are supposed to be discussing-these so 'horrific' amendments. First of all, let us address the so-called health and housing amendment which we are saying is changing the nature of the bill. That amendment says that when the ILC is giving grants to Aborigi- Leichhardt. nal communities buying the land it should look at what is going to happen with that land. Will the people be able to provide housing on the land? Will they be able to provide sealed roads? One of the big problems in Aboriginal health is the dust from the unsealed roads getting into people's eyes. Where there is not sufficient water for continual washing we get infectious diseases. Thatbrings up the second point. Should the ILC buy a piece of land where there is no available good ground water-there may be water that is too brackish to use-and where there is no piped water? How is that going to affectthe health of the Aboriginal people who move into that community? It means that we are going to see more pictures similar to those that we. saw when Graham Richardson went to Central Australia. We saw Aboriginal people living in humpies in a state of health that is reminiscent of Third World countries. I do not know how the people in the gallery feel about that but, as an Australian, I am absolutely appalled and ashamed that we have people in Australia who live in that condition. I might remind those opposite that these people live in that condition after 12 years of Labor government. Our amendment did not say to the ILC, 'Don't buy the land.' It said, 'Look, when you are buying the land for heaven's sake take these things into consideration: is there sewerage; how is that land going to be serviced by water; are you going to buy apiece of land that Aboriginal people will move on to and then find that they do not have water to wash?' The kids will be playing in the sewerage and will come up again and again with those infectious diseases that the rest of Australia has not seen since the last century. Was this such a terrible amendment to this bill? It was an amendment that did not say, 'Don't buy the land'; it simply said, 'When you buy the land look at what is going to happen afterwards and think of the health of Aboriginal people on that land.' It was an essential amendment. Mr Dodd-Ten per cent cut in Fightback.

You have some concerns from talking to Aboriginal people. Let's sit down and discuss your amendments'? No, they did not. Mr Gibson-You made up this amendment without any consultation whatsoever.

Title: COMMITTEE ON NATIVE TITLE AND

Speaker: Mrs GALLUS
Title: COMMITTEE ON NATIVE TITLE AND
text: What happened when it got to the Senate? There was a little bit of difference in the Senate. Suddenly the amendments were not so bad and the government agreed to pass them. That was a nice backflip on the part of the government which the Prime Minister has not mentioned. I would like to get on to some of the other amendments that are important. I refer to the attitude about individual trusts. The government has tried to mislead the Australian public by saying that our amendment meant that we would be handing land to individual people. If the government would care to read the amendment it would find that it said that the Indigenous Land Corporation, the body that buys the land, can give the land to corporations-which is in the bill at the moment---or individuals or trusts. It does not say that the ILC has to do this; it simply widens the options. The Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) read from a quotation which indicated that corporations are not a natural form for Aboriginal people. For most of those people family trusts are a much more understandable form. We did not even say, 'You have to give it to family trusts.' We we would widen the legislation to allow the Indigenous Land Corporation to provide for family trusts as well as corporations if that was what the Indigenous Land Corporation so decided. The amendment was simply to give the ILC more power to consider those Aboriginal people who are not comfortable with corporations. Does that surprise people? How many here today really understand corporations? When you ask an Aboriginal community, with an overall extremely low level of literacy and a non-understanding of what goes on in the commercial world, to form a corporation, you are really asking it to do something which is alien to its whole traditional culture. Yet that is what this government says is the natural form for Aboriginal people. It has. decided that that is what is right for Aboriginal people and to hell with the rest of the community, and to hell with those Aboriginal people who came to us saying, 'The government did not consult with us. We cannot live with the bill in this form. Would you please get the bill amended so it applies to us?' The government is very sensitive about our proposal for the extra $3 million. Most of the Australian public, despite our efforts to get the information out, are not aware that the coalition and the Greens in the Senate actually voted for an extra $3 million to go into the land fund for administration. The request was rushed into this House so quickly that I do not think that members on the other side even knew what was happening. It was in and out in a few seconds. There is a land fund. We thOUght that it was important that the money in the land fund be spent only on land and not be eaten up in administration, the way so much money is in these areas. We said that we would vote $3 million into the fund for administration but that that was all that could be spent on administration; the rest of the money would be for the purchase of land. What did the government do? It said, 'No way.' It rushed that request out of the Senate arid into the House without any warning. I was in my room at the time. If I had not been said able to run as fast as I can, I would have missed it altogether and would not have been able to tell this House what our position was. The Whip was given one minute's notice, and that is how long it took me to get out of my room. It was a despicable act on the part of the government, getting the request back into this House without allowing for proper debate on the extra $3 million. What did the government do then? It marsh circulated amongst the general community not that we had voted an extra $3 million for administration, but that we had simply wanted to cap administration expenses. There was mention of the extra money. It sent out letters to Aboriginal people, misleading them on this whatsoever. point, saying that we wanted to cap administration and that it thought that was an unreaamendments sonable fettering of the ILC. I turn now to the issue of traditional ownerin ship. One of our amendments was designed to require the ILC to consult with traditional owners prior to the acquisition of land or making a grant for the acquisition of land. thought it was an extremely sensible amend which ment and we are yet to discover why the government knocked it back. If the ILC is buying land for one group of Aboriginal people, it makes sense that, first of all, the traditional people be consulted with. If it is buying land for traditional people, that is fine. But what happens if the ILC believes that it is buying land for one group of Abopeople, riginal people while there are other Aboriginal people who have traditionally used that land-people who may not have a claim under the Mabo legislation because the land affairs. was subject to a pastoral lease? Their Mabo claim has been wiped out, yet they have been traditional owners. What will be the result for those two tribes of Aboriginal people? The result will be fighting, argument and bloodshed. Yet the government, because it refuses to consider sensible amendments, purely for party political reasons, totally refused that amendment. In conclusion, I sum up my reaction as one of incredible disappointment at the way in which the government has decided to use Aboriginal affairs not only as a political football but as a way of scoring political points when out there is one of the most serious problems facing Australia today. (Time expired) Mr GmSON (Moreton) (12.20 p.m.)-The shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, the member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), appealed to the gallery during her speech. appeal to the gallery to discount everything has just heard from the member for Hindonly because she has just engaged in a total rewrite of history. Let us not forget that most of the amendments we are discussing here today were amendments that she brought into no this House before she had had one ounce of consultation with any Aboriginal people One of the major reasons why most of the were rejected by the government in the first place was that she had not engaged any sort of consultation. In fact, she was told very clearly right across the board that most of her amendments were not acceptable to Aboriginal people. The opposition then set We up this farce of a Senate select committee spent a week at Christmas time running around desperately trying to get a few people in Aboriginal Australia to back its opinions. It did manage to find a few people who would say, 'Yes, I agree with this one,' or 'I agree with that one.' But the fact is that the Senate has absolutely no expertise in Aboriginal affairs. It is great at bagging Aboriginal it is great at knocking ATSIC and it is great at engaging in political campaigns against Aboriginal interests, but it has not done any real hard work on Aboriginal The only really good intensive discussion of Aboriginal affairs in a balanced and reasonable way occurs in this House. We have the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, which has been in existence for 17 years, and which I am proud to be the chair of at this time. It has a long history and, because of the work of that committee, we actually engage in much greater consultation amongst Aboriginal people. Over the last five years I have been on that committee, I have visited probably over 100 Aboriginal communities and have spoken to thousands of Aboriginal people-a hell of a lot more than the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs has done. I know a lot more about Aboriginal affairs than the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs says. I would like to make just one point. The I coalition was able to get away with a lot of it the amendments it put forward in the Senate because of the unholy alliance it had with the Western Australian Greens. It greatly disappoints me that the Western Australian Greens were willing to sell their souls to the coalition on this deal. They put this bill through months of delay, forced through the Senate a whole pile of amendments and then did not even have the guts to stand up in the Senate and vote for it. They avoided it. They abstained from the vote. That is how strong their commitment is to Aboriginal people and how strong their commitment is to the amendments. They did not even have the guts to vote on the bill when it went into the Senate. That just shows you exactly what the Greens are worth. It is a worthless organisation, and the miserable two in the Senate at the moment will be decimated at the next election. Regardless of the cowardly motives of the opposition in wanting to avoid a double dissolution and facing the people of Australia where they know they are going to be beaten, I am pleased that the coalition has agreed to vote for the second government bill when it comes to the House next Tuesday, because I am sick of the unnecessary delays that have occurred. I am strongly in support of this land acquisition fund. I believe it is a very important hew initiative in social justice for Aborigichamber. nal people. I just wish the people on the other side would really start talking about accountability and start targeting state and territory governments. Let us not forget who has the major responsibility for the provision of health services throughout this country-state and territory governments. Who is responsible for building housing, building roads and putting in water supplies? State, territory and local governments. It is they that have been failing in their responsibilities. The opposition never talks about or accepts that. It comes in here and talks about states rights all the time, but it never talks about states responsibilities. It is about time states responsibilities in Aboriginal affairs started getting an airing in this House.

Speaker: Mr NUGENT
Title: COMMITTEE ON NATIVE TITLE AND
text: I came into this chamber this morning from the middle of a meeting with a subcommittee of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation where we are working on the council's recommendations to the government for the social justice package. I would like to spend the few minutes that I have available to me this morning perhaps trying to move away a little from some of the hot air, self-righteous indignation and accusations that have been flowing around and talk about some constructive things for our indigenous population. I would urge the government to grasp the opportunity that is now clearly before it that this legislation is going to go through the parliament. The fact that we are goil)g to vote against this particular piece of legislation this morning to support our Senate colleagues but have indicated quite clearly that when the second bill comes on next week we will not oppose it gives the government an opportunity not to have to put lots of its effort, energies, time and rhetoric into that piece of legislation but to now turn its attention to doing some constructive things in so many other areas of urgent and desperate Aboriginal need. There is no question that we all accept the importance of land to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The way in which that is expressed might vary from person to person or community to community, and there may be different strengths and views within this BuUhe fundamental recognition is there and the coalition has accepted that principle with this bill throughout. I think we also need to be conscious that there are a number of areas where, unfortunately, the government's good intentions-and I accept that the minister has acted with good intentions for a long time in so many other areas of Aboriginal disadvantage, such as health, housing, education, employment and so on-have not borne the fruits that we would all like to have seen. The reality is that health is still a major dIsaster in this country. The one statistic that comes back to me repeatedly is life expectancy-IS years less for an Aboriginal male born today compared with somebody in the wider community, and for females it is 15 years. If we look at the housing situation, we are talking about $2 billion just to catch up on the backlog. If we ·Iook at levels of education, we realise it is not just education but it is all interlinked. Health impacts on that as well with so many of our Aboriginal children going to school with middle ear infection that they have not got a hope in either the health or the education stakes. And unemployment is so much worse in the indigenous community. We clearly have a number of problems with the A TSIC experiment. Without bucketing, in any sense, ATSIC-and I have been one of its strongest supporters in this place-there are quite clearly a number of areas that need addressing, and the government should be giving it that attention. I urge the government in dealing with these matters to go out and consult with the Aboriginal community on a far wider basis than it did with this land bill. I think it has had a tendency to deal with Aboriginal people who are elected to ATSIC, but unfortunately they do not representthe majority. They have dealt with the land councils but there are many others in Aboriginal communities who hold contrary views and who need to be consulted. In my role since I have come into this parliament I have been to many of those communities regularly and I can assure the House that although the government is claiming its views are so unanimously supported, that is simply not the case. I am concerned that the government has chosen to take a divisive attitude in so many areas of Aboriginal affairs. To hear the Prime Minister talk about the need for cross-party support and then come in here and say, 'Now I am going to pull this second bill, I am going to introduce a third bill next week,' seems to me to be merely trying to take party political advan- Gear, G. tage. I would have thought the interests of indigenous people in this country would have been far better served by accepting that the coalition is going to not oppose the second bill and to then get on with the urgent business of dealing with Aboriginal disadvantage. The government is talking about its three tranches-the native title legislation, the land fund and the social justice package which is upcoming and essentially about rights. They are all important to indigenous people and most people in this chamber acceptthe principles. But we argue about the implementation. I really urge the government to change its priorities now that it has a guarantee of getting that legislation through and to turn its attention much more to dealing with those practical things on the ground because when I go to Aboriginal communities that is what they tell me they want fixed.
