Speaker: Mr TICKNER
Title: AYES
text: Hughes-Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs) (12.39 p.m.)-I move: That the Senate's further amendments Nos 1 to 3, 18 to 22, 28 to 30, 34, 36 to 40, 44, 49, to 62, 64, 66, and 67 (Group 2) be agreed to. As has already been said by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), only a Labor government could deliver legislation to produce this land fund. But, in debating the bill currently before the House, we now turn to amendments which have been agreed to by the AYES government. In doing so, I must emphasise that the government has, once again, shown its bona fides and its good faith in agreeing to some 29 amendments made by the Senate to the land fund bill. What we are not prepared to do is agree to amendments which are bad law and that NOES would make, for example, grants to individual people on one day and allow the land to' be sold off the next day with a total absence of accountability. However, the 29 ame,ndments that we are accepting is evidence of our commitment to try to achieve the greatest degree of cross-party support. The coalition is now indicating that it will support the Prime Minister's bill because of the fear of a double dissolution. As the minister, I welcome the support for whatever reason, although the point about the coalition's motivation, which has been made in a very telling way, shows how scared the coalition is to face a full Senate election. Notwithstanding the government's concern on a number of issues about the Senate amendments, we think that the additional operational burdens on the Indigenous Land Corporation are survivable if these amendments are accepted. We believe ,that one of them - a Democrat amendment-clearly improves the bill. It is the so-called 'top-up' amendment, No. 57, which provides that, if at the end of a 10-year period the land fund does not reach the investment target expected of it, an extra amount will be paid from PAIRS consolidated revenue to top up the land fund. That is a very important guarantee which ensures that after the initial 10 years the fund will be self-sustaining. A number of other amendments which the government is prepared to accept are technical ones. For example, the title of the bill has been changed, the minister will be required to table the national strategy in parliament within 50, 57 15 days of receiving· it and the terms and conditions which the Indigenous Land Corporation may impose on a loan is spelt out rather than left to the discretion of the Indigenous Land Corporation. Still other amendments have been accepted by us .because they do not fundamentally offend the spirit of the bill and, of course, those amendments are incorporated in the new bill that the Prime Minister introduced into the parliament. An example of that would be the provision that the ILC must report to the minister if its obligations not to reveal secret material affects its functions. In view of the prolonged debate that this bill has received, and the fact that the government is accepting the amendments that I am currently speaking about, I will truncate my remarks and allow opposition speakers to make a contribution.

Speaker: Mrs GALLUS
Title: AYES
text: Hindmarsh) (12.43 p.m.)I will also make my comments brief because the government has decided to shorten this debate. I know there are many people on my side who would have a lot to say but, unfortunately, they will not be able to do so. May I clearly point out to the minister sitting at the table, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), that we would like nothing more than to go to an election right now. You know what would happen to you: you would be so far out there that you wouldn't get a look in. Can I say that, as a member with a marginal seat, an election right now would be great, because I can see myself adding to my margin by another 10 to 15 per cent. Let us have no talk about the coalition being scared to go to a double dissolution. The coalition would be delighted to have an election today, tomorrow or whenever you would like. Can I also point out that the coalition is more interested in getting this place running properly and having good government rather than' having a government that is run by the larrikin that you call a prime minister, who cannot see beyond the cheap political trick. Everything the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) says has to be political point scoring, and that is why we are in this state with the government today. When we refer to Aboriginal affairs, after 12 years of this government there are Aboriginal people still living in humpies, dying and without access to water. On these amendments that the government has accepted, after they appeared in the House of Representatives the government, through the minister at the table, said, 'We will not pass any of these amendments. These are all terrible amendments. We will not touch them with a barge pole. Get them out of here. We will not consider them.' But, 10 and behold, what happened when it got to the Senate was that 23 of them were suddenly not so bad after all and the government said, 'Okay, we will pass 23 of them.' That is how much you can put on the word of this government: one day they are untouchable amendments; the next day, when they get to the Senate, 23 of them are passed. What does that say about the integrity of this government? What does that say about the sincerity of the government when it originally saw the amendments? It says that the government has no sincerity in this area. It is not interested in anything else except politics. So we have these 23 amendments to which the government agrees. Obviously, we are going to agree to them in the House. One amendment provides that at least two members of the ILC board must have business expertise. We moved that amendment in this House when the bill originally came up, saying that two members of the ILC board must have business experience, otherwise you could have a board with no business expertise running a $1 billion land fund. We put that to the minister in this House and the minister ridiculed it. The minister said, 'No way. We will not consider this amendment. It is a terrible amendment.' He could not tell us why, of course. What has happened? It has come back from the Senate and the government has agreed with that amendment because it is obviously essential. What does that tell you about the minister sitting at the table and his ability to judge this area correctly and to be sincere in the area?

Speaker: Ms HENZELL
Title: AYES
text: I am pleased to have the opportunity to contribute to this debate on the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994. I was shocked and horrified to hear an appalling statement by the Leader of the Opposition, the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). One of the Greens (WA) senators, Senator Margetts, described our new bill as a 'sham'. The only sham revealed has been the incapacity of the opposition to get its act together. Today, the Leader of the Opposition came into this House and said, 'We don't agree with this. We supported the holding up of the legislation in the Senate for all this time, but we don't want a double dissolution, so we're going to let this go through.' And he confidently said, 'When we get into government.' I do not believe that confidence is based on a great deal. A week is a long time in politics, and the next few weeks will show the difference. The Leader of the Opposition repeated what his predecessor said. When he was in Western Australia, I believe the member for Mayo (Mr Downer) said, 'We're going to change the native title legislation.' Today, the Leader of the Opposition has come in and said, 'We are going to vote for this legislation but when it'Mr Nehl- Mr Speaker, on a point of order: perhaps you could direct the member for Capricornia to speak on the bill before the House, not the Native Title Act.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: AYES
text: The honourable member for Cowper, I think, has been here through the whole of the debate. Some latitude has been given to the matters that have been raised under this. I will extend the same latitude to the member for Capricornia.

Speaker: Ms HENZELL
Title: AYES
text: -What the Leader of the Opposition said typifies the sort of leadership we can expect from the member for Bennelong. He said, 'We are going to vote for this legislation and, if we become the government, we are going to vote it out again.' What can the people of this country expect? They can expect the same sort of shillyshallying that they got from the former leader over other aspects of Aboriginal policy. In this debate, once again, the opposition has no planned policy on Aboriginal affairs. Opposition members get up and criticise us because we have not been able to fix the wrongs of 200 years. But we have demonstrated a commitment to righting the wrongs of 200 years. It is indeed the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) who has shown true leadership on this issue. In response to the motion on the previous amendments, the Leader of the Opposition said, 'We're not in the guilt industry.' I want to comment on this issue because these land fund measures are about Australia taking responsibility for its past. As a collective, all the present citizens. of this country have a collective responsibility for past wrongs just, indeed, as I hope we would see that Germany has a collective responsibility for its wrongs done to minorities during the Second World War and just as we would expect the Japanese to have a collective responsibility for the wrongs done to our POWs. To say that we will not have any truck with the guilt industry is an absolute disgrace. It is my view, very strongly held, that until we as a community accept our ·responsibility for these issues and acknowledge them, as indeed has been done by the Prime Minister in his Redfern speech, in his second reading speeches on the two land fund bills before this parliament and in his speech at Hopevale, there is no real chance of reconciliation. This bill is about land and is about the Aboriginal people's spiritual involvement with the land. There will only be a change in all the other issues that concern both sides of the House in terms of Aboriginal welfare and the need for infrastructure and an economic basis for development if Aboriginal people have some access to the land. The aim of this bill is to make sure that for those communities who cannot get justice through the Mabo legislation there will be access to land, independence and a return to their spiritual roots. I certainly support the comments of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner).

Speaker: Mr NEHL
Title: AYES
text: I must indicate my thanks to the honourable member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell) for finishing early and allowing me some time to speak on the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill. Having thanked her, I must refer to her statement that the government has demonstrated its commitment. The government has demonstrated its commitment to failure of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. If we look at the areas of health, education, housing and employment-everywhere we look-it is a record of failure. The government has been in office for 12 years. What has happened in those 12 years? Aboriginal men still have a life expectancy 18 years less than me. In fact, probably almost every Aboriginal man born the year that I was born is dead already. That is the likelihood, and that is a disgrace and a shame. Aboriginal women have 15 years less life expectancy than my wife. How can we, and my friends on the other side of the House, talk about responsibility, commitment and guilt? If there is to be any guilt in this parliament today it is guilt for the inactivity and failure of the last 12 years-.:.not for the last 200. We have to be concerned about what is happening now and in the future. We should learn from the past, but we cannot live there-we have to go forward; . What is absolutely unkind about this legislation is that it cruelly raises the expectations of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I ask the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) at the table: what is in this bill for Torres Strait Islanders? I would be pleased if it could be demonstrated to me that there is one single benefit for Torres Strait Islander people in this bill. When the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was speaking. I noticed that he made mention specifically of Aborigines. I wonder whether the Prime Minister, in all the 25 years he has been here, has ever made a specific reference to the problems of Torres Strait Islanders and the Torres Strait without just tagging it onto the ATSIC label. I have been through Hansard as far back as 1981. Perhaps it has been mentioned in answers to questions, but certainly in speeches the number of times the Prime Minister has mentioned the Torres Strait could be counted on the fingers of both hands, and then it has only been tagged onto Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs. I do not think that is good enough. I flag this particular point because the Torres Strait is an area of great interest to me personally. I have a lot of friends there, and I go there from time to time. I am really concerned about what this bill will do for people in the Torres Strait. I said that this bill will cruelly raise expectations. Technically we are talking about $1.5 billion being made available over 10 years. Nobody should believe for one second that $1.5 billion will be there to buy land. That is not the case. It will be put in a trust fund and invested, and the interest-about $45 million a year-will be made available for land purchases. I believe that this bill is a sham, and I have believed that ever since the bill was introduced. It cruelly raises expectations. Already, $21 million a year has been provided to A TSIC for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to buy land, so there is a net increase of only about $24 million. I hope the minister will be able to inform me if I am wrong. I hope I am wrong because I do not believe that this sort of confidence trick on the indigenous people of Australia is at all appropriate. The Prime Minister spoke about justice for Aboriginal people. They are being denied justice in the important areas of health, housing and education. The honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) spoke about the ATSIC leadership representing all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I do not think for one second that the ATSIC leadership represents the people in my electorate who live at New Burnt Bridge. The minister at the table will recall visiting New Burnt Bridge with me. I have praised him many times since then for going and I do so again. I also applaud his commitment, as he provided $2.3 million for it. But I come back to the fact that, although the money has already been provided, years later not a single house has been built and people are still living in disgraceful Third World conditions. They complained to the Ombudsman because of a dispute with the regional office of ATSIC at Lismore. What has ATSIC done? It has taken out injunctions to stop the Ombudsman's report going to this minister, the Prime Minister and this parliament. I do not believe ATSIC enjoys the confidence of all Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander people at all. In fact, I know that to be true. I will complete my remarks so the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) will have at least a couple of minutes to speak. This bill is not what it seems. It provides ° about an extra $24 million a year in new money for 1 years, and it is not going to do what is required of it. I come back to the point that we must solve the health, housing, education and employment problems. We have had 12 years of failure by the present government. It should face up to the event. I say this to all of those on the government who talk about elections: if you want an election, bring one on now. We are ready and we will beat you.

Speaker: Mr LES SCOTT
Title: AYES
text: In the couple of minutes available to me, I would like to respond to some of the silly criticisms made by the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Neh!). In this debate on the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill we really should not be making those sorts of criticisms. We should take a bipartisan approach to assisting Aboriginal people. It is all very well for the member for Cowper to blame everything on the last 12 years, but I suggest we should look at what has happened in the last 200 years or so. That is the big problem. Until all of us in this place sit down and work together on this issue-instead of the nonsense opposition members have been going on with over the last few months-we are never going to assist the Aboriginal people in this country. It really is disgraceful Crosio, J. A. that opposition members have carried on in the manner they have. They have dragged out this whole process and then have come in here today and caved in. They should have done months ago what they have done today, even though, as the Prime Minister and other speakers today have said, they have done it only for their own political reasons. Opposition members really carryon in a disgraceful way. They have been dishonest throughout this whole process. They have been dishonest with their own constituencies and certainly the people of Australia. Some of the stupid amendments put up by opposition members-such as having land entrusted to people in their individual names-would not achieve anything this bill is trying to achieve. That is why we have been trying to convince them all the time. They are not being honest with the people of Australia on this, and it is about time they were. It is about time they really worked in the best interests of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in Australia.

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: by leave-I rise to make a statement about shipping in and around our unique national treasure, the Great Barrier Reef. Presently, ships use two routes to traverse the reef. What is known as the inner route travels from the Torres Strait in the north, to Gladstone in the south. The alternative route-the outer route-comPAIRS mences in the Prince of Wales Channel, leaves the Torres Strait at Bligh Entrance, and continues southwards through the Coral Sea to Sandy Cape, just south of Gladstone. All ships entering and leaving the inner and outer routes have to cross the Torres Strait. At present, pilotage is compulsory in the inner route between Cairns and the Torres Strait for all oil and chemical tankers and liquid natural gas carriers, regardless of size, and all other ships over 70 metres in length. The most hazardous parts of the reef to by navigate are in the. Torres Strait and in the northern section of the inner passage. Narrow channels, strong tides and the presence of fishing boats all enhance the risk of a ground- crew. ing. Furthermore, in the case of the outer route, the process of skirting the reef and the largely uncharted waters pose a similar risk of grounding. With some 87 million tonnes of international trade-mostly Australian exports-shipped through the region annually, this ever present danger is a matter of great concern. Altogether, there are some 2,100 local and international vessel movements annually, including 1,700 through the inner route, 600 of which do not call at any Queensland port inside the reef. This leaves some 400 vessels using the outer. route. Whilst pilotage in the inner route is, as I said, mandatory for all and chemical tankers, liquid natural gas carriers and other ships over 70 metres in length, it is not compulsory in the internationnised al waters of the Torres Strait. Each year, 30 loaded oil tankers enter the Torres Strait and transit the inner route, a similar number travel north along the inner route under ballast. Twenty tankers transit the outer route southward. The government considers that there is no compelling reason for those 30 tankers not to join the 20 tankers using the outer route southward. Few Australians would think of the Great Barrier Reef as a shipping lane. It is seen by most as a precious natural asset-and, indeed, it is. That is certainly the view of the governfinalised ment, and that is why we are determined to take all reasonable steps to minimise the potential for shipping disaster. But in doing so we must strike a balance between protecting the natural environment and maintaining viable shipping lanes. The government has already taken a number of significant steps to safeguard the reef and to improve safety in shipping. Last September I announced new administrative procedures for issuing single voyage permits to foreign vessels. This places an obligation on shippers to undertake thorough safety checks before chartering foreign vessels. This condition came into effect this week. In addition, shippers applying for permits involving bulk carriers and all types of tankers must now certify vital information on the condition of the ship, as well as the qualifications of its As part of the government's response to the House of Representatives Ships of shame report, targeted inspections have doubled and now more than one in two foreign flagged vessels are subject to inspection when they call into Australian ports. This rigorous inspection regime has unquestionably deterred substandard shippers from calling into Australia. Today we can boast the toughest inspection regime in the world; one in which monthly ship detention reports are published to bring substandard shipping to worldwide attention. In terms of the reef itself, by introducing a oil regime of compulsory pilotage for the inner route in October 1991, Australia made this transit route one of the world's few recogcompulsory pilotage areas. More recently, in October 1993, the government announced a detailed review of shipping while in the Great Barrier Reef and the Torres Strait. We did so to ensure that the management of shipping operations maximises environmental protection and minimises the risk of accidents and pollution. This review has been conducted in conjunction with the Queensland government. A wide range of interested parties, including the shipping industry and environmental groups, has been consulted. The report is presently being and will be released by the government soon. Nevertheless, today I want to announce a number of initiatives that will improve the safety of shipping in the Great Barrier Reef and the Torres Strait. The initiatives involve minimising shipping pressure on the inner route; additional steps to improve the safety of ships that use the inner route; improved navigational safety in the Torres Strait; and improving the safety and the reliability of the outer route. We are undertaking these initiatives in the knowledge that many vessels use the Great Barrier Reef inner route because of a lack of suitable charting of the outer route through the Coral Sea. In order to improve the charting of the outer reef, I can today announce that the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, AMSA, will provide funding for the production of these charts. The task will involve surveying that will begin at Bramble Cay in the eastern approaches to the Torres go down the Queensland coast to the end of the reef just north of Fraser Island, a total distance of some 2,000 kilometres. Once this charting is done, those vessels not calling at Queensland ports that currently use the inner route, will, unless there are exceptional circumstances, have absolutely no reason to do so. Simultaneously with this charting, AM SA will proceed with the introduction of a mandatory ship reporting regime for the Great Barrier Reef and the Torres Strait. AMSA will also seek to implement a reporting system with the agreement of the International Maritime Organisation, IMO, and will aim to have the measures in place before the end of this year. Meanwhile I can assure the House that the Queensland government has been cooperating with the Commonwealth in moving towards the introduction of a vessel traffic system to cover both the North East Channel and the Torres Strait. The Commonwealth is very grateful for the Queensland government's assistance with this task. Together, AMSA and the Queensland government have been looking very closely at initiatives to improve maritime safety in northern waters. Extensive studies by consultants of potential high-technology solutions the navigational problems of the region have now been completed. AM SA and the Queensland government are now negotiating joint ventures to ensure these initiatives can be introduced at the earliest time and in the most cost-effective way. One of the first stages of this cooperative approach will be the introduction of a vessel traffic system to cover the Torres Strait, the Great North Eastern Channel route near Cape York, and the inner route. Extended coverage of this radar traffic system will provide accurate real time information and reduce the prospect of ship collision and groundings. This will be a vast improvement on the present situation where authorities rely on positions radioed in from vessels. It will provide cover of, and information relating to the important 'choke' points - where channels are narrow and the hazard to shipping is Strait and greatly increased. Furthermore, it will assist the Australian and the Queensland agencies involved in vessel traffic to enhance safety by monitoring vessel movements more closely. Extension of the compulsory pilotage area in the northern part of the Great Barrier Reef to cover the Torres Strait area would further reduce the risk of groundings and collisions. After all, human error is the greatest risk to safe shipping. The Torres Strait is an important and busy international shipping lane and Australia must be cognisant of the role of our neighbour, Papua New Guinea, and the international maritime community in seeking ways to improve safety in this ecologically vulnerable region. As the Torres Strait is a recognised international waterway, the extension of compulsory pilotage will involve comprehensive international negotiations. A successful outcome· to these negotiations will be far more difficult to achieve than for the Barrier Reef, which lies totally within Australian waters. I have asked AM SA to pursue the question of compulsory pilotage in the Torres Strait. Indeed, it will now become AM SA 's highest international priority in negotiations through the IMO. It is pleasing to note that around 70 per cent of shipping that is currently transiting to the Torres Strait already uses marine pilots on a voluntary basis. Yet there are a number of foreign flag vessels which place commercial considerations before their .environmental conscience. We now intend to seek international acceptance of the need to carry pilots in these waters. While insisting on the greater use of pilotage in the marine environments, we recognise that technology is constantly offering new ways to improve safety. The latest differential global positioning systems, DGPS, offer improved navigational safety. With DGPS, positioning accuracy is better than 10 metres. This technology is now available and is being trialled successfully by AM SA in Bass Strait and off the Pilbara. Today I announce the establishment of new DGPS broadcasting station on Hom Island in the Torres Strait. It will be by October this year and will greatly improve the accuracy of ship positioning and assist individual ships to navigate safely in these difficult waters. With the establishment of this station AMSA will insist on the compulsory use by pilots of transportable global positionmodel ing equipment. This will ensure that all ships being piloted do so with the benefit of the improved DGPS navigational services. The next few years will see the introduction of computer based charting systems that rapid response. provide further improvements to all navigational systems on all types of vessels. As now, a large amount of work has ;ilieady been completed on this technology. The develophave ment of such a system can and should have implications beyond just the reef. It has the capacity to extend to all of our precious Australian coastline. That makes it a huge undertaking. Such technology is costly develop but it is an investment that Australia must make in the interests of our marine environment and the safety of shipping. To this day, shipping oil spills greatest threat to our coastline. They are a constant threat over which we must be forever vigilant. Vigilance will help prevention or, the event of an unavoidable spillage, the ability to minimise the damage to our marine environment. The Australian government is in the process of negotiating a memorandum of understanda ing with Papua New Guinea on cooperation and assistance in the event of a marine pollution incident affecting either country. of particular relevance to the Torres Strait. There is already considerable cooperation with Papua New Guinea involving AM SA providing significant assistance to the PNG government. Following a major review of· Natplan in 1993, some 30 recommendations were made to improve planning and the capacity to respond to a major spill. Twenty-six actions have now been implemented and the remainfrom ing four are to be completed by the end of 1995. Actions relevant to the Great Barrier Reef include: the positioning of additional a equipment in North Queensland and training for its use; development of a MOO between opened AMSA, Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, GBRMPA, and Queensland for safe havens for disabled or damaged ships; priority for research funding going to a bioremediation· proposal to be managed by the GBRMPA; and extension of the on scene spill to cover the Ribbon Reefs area. Reefplan, the regional version of Natplan, is currently undergoing its own review, which will be completed in mid-1995. The emphasis will be on prevention, on planning and on a When taken together as a package, all these of federal government measures enhance shipping safety in this most sensitive of areas. We a great responsibility to current and future generations to protect what is the world's biggest and most beautiful reef, one of the world's great ecological treasures. As a maritime enthusiast it gives me great pleasto ure to detail these important government initiatives aimed at protecting what we all hold dear. They are balanced initiatives, yet initiatives with foresight. I commend the remain the statement to the House.

Speaker: Mr SHARP
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: Thank you very much, Mr in Deputy Speaker, for your guidance. There no doubt that, for those of us who have had an interest in this issue, this does advance the cause of protecting the Great Barrier Reef. number of people in the chamber today would have heard debates going back over the few years; there has been a great deal of concern and interest from both sides of the House. Indeed, I was going through my own by speeches from the last few years and I that, on 28 November 1988, I said in this House: Talk of damage to the Great Barrier Reef is great concern to Australia, not just from a recreation and aesthetic point of view, but also from economic and employment point of view. In May 1991, we had the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill introduced into the House, and it introduced compulsory pilotage. Unfortunately for the those of who wanted to debate the issue, the guillotine was applied and only the minister's speech was allowed to be heard in the House at the time. Certainly, on that occasion the opposithe tion supported the compulsory pilotage that was put forward at the time. There have been a number of issues in that recent times. We have had bills about oil pollution at sea. The honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) has spoken, I think, on virtually all of these. In relation to the port Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, I said: I personally support the amendments that relate to the prevention of pollution from ships. Another was the Protection of Sea (Shipping Levy) Amendment Bill 1993. I refer to speech I made when I represented the opposiplough tion on that matter. We supported attempts, that time, to investigate alternative routes outside the reef. Indeed, it is an interesting point. The minister might like to consider the fact that, at the time, Caltex offered an $80,000 sponsorship to assist in studies on alternative routes outside the reef. I was listening to the minister's speech today, and there was no to mention of that. I wonder whether that sponsorship was ever taken up. Perhaps, if it were, it would be a nice thing to thank Caltex the process. Many people think that our is shipping companies are not as environmentally responsible as people would like to think, yet there have been instances, as is the A case with Caltex, where not only have they tried to be responsible but also they have put last their money where their mouths are. Indeed, Shell is another example. Shell's oil tankers have been travelling outside the reef now for quite some time, in an attempt made Shell to ensure that it creates minimal risk noticed of damage to the Great Barrier Reef. So, there have been a number of shipping companies and oil companies doing their very of best to assist in ensuring that we do not have the any accidents on the reef. Of course, there have been many others who have not, but at least it is worth noting those who have been helping. Throughout all of this, from the opposius tion's point of view and, indeed, from the government's point of view, we have been very keen to do the utmost to protect the reef. The reason the minister is bringing this into House today is that, whilst it would seem logical to have all ships go outside the reef, other than those ships which have to call into ports along the reef, there have been concerns the shipping lanes outside, to the east of, the reef have not been adequately charted. Many old salts will tell you that the original Transcharting that was done many years ago was done very poorly; some, apparently, was not done at all. A lot of the navigational aids are very old and not up to the task today. Of course, that has been a concern, because, if you do not have properly charted waters so a that you can be confident that ships can through those waters without running at into anything, it is probably safer to have ships going inside the reef where there are proper charts. With proper navigational aids and compulsory pilotage, that was probably safer than going outside the reef, at the time. There is no doubt that the initiatives announced today by the minister will ensure that, over time, channels outside the reef become a lot safer, with the addition of proper charting and more navigational aids. That is something that I think will advance a cause that both sides of this House would support: making sure that our Great Barrier Reef is protected as much as it can be. The compulsory DGPS through the Torres Strait is really an essential element. I have actually taken a boat, many years ago now, through the Torres Strait, and at that point you get the Indian and Pacific oceans meeting. You get currents that clash at that point-they go in different directions-you get whirlpools; it is really quite dramatic if you go through that part of the world in a boat. It is a very dangerous waterway. The channels are very narrow, those channels are quite shallow as well, and there is quite a lot of shipping that goes through. So it is really vital that, if we are to advance the cause - ll of u- in this House support, we get that mternatIonal agreement, if you like, with compulsory DGPSs for ships going through that part of the world. It is something that we should promote as quickly as possible. As the minister has pointed out, computer based charting is something that will further enhance our attempts to protect the Great Barrier Reef and it should be seen as a great priority. I hope I am quoting the minister correctly where he talks of the time span for these things over the next few years, and I would hope that we could be more definite. Rather than just saying 'over the next few years', we should actually set ourselves a particular schedule that we could work to so that this gives people the impetus to get on with the job, because when you say, 'We are going to do it over the next few years,' you can never be confident that all the bureaucrats and diplomats that are involved in achieving these things are working at maximum speed. Many of us, as I said earlier, have taken a long and deep interest in this issue. I have visited the oil spill centre in Geelong. For anybody who has an interest in this matter and who has not visited that centre I think it is a very worthwhile thing to do. is sponsored by the oil companies. It is one of our front-line .defences if we do have an oil spill. will That remmds me of the Auditor-Geheral's report No. 9 of 1994-95, which wa- tabled some time ago now. That report looked into ?ur ability to respond to a major oil spill, and m the process identified the Great Barrier Reef as a high risk area. I quote from the report's conclusion: The ANAO considers that with the technology c-lITe-tly availabl-there is no certainty that a major Oil spill can be dispersed before it impacts on the shoreline. This is something that we need to be looking at also, that we must have the equipment necessary to ensure that we can deal with a major oil spill in this part of the world. The downside to travelling outside the reef is that if you do have an oil spill occurring at that point, . the winds and the currents along that coasthne are such that you actually will drive the oil, or whatever chemical spills out of the that ship, across the entire width of the reef whereas, as happened in the past, where yocome up through the middle of the reef you run the risk of putting oil over only half of the - e-f, if you like. That is a simple analogy, but It IS roughly right. By going outside the reef we do increase !h- - rea potentially affected by an oil spill, so It IS Important that we also do what we can to ens!l-- that we have g?t oil spill recovery facIlitIes to ensure that If something does go wrong we can do our very best to mop it up. The one thing that we all worry about, apart from the ecological damage, is the television news reports around the world that would - isplay ou- Great Barrier Reef in a very poor hght, and It would do our tourism industry a great deal of harm. We all have memories of the Exxon Valdez going down in Prince William Sound and the oil spill that was portrayed for weeks after that on the television. It promoted a bad image. We all remember the Kirki, and we were very fortunate that that did not do much damage in the long term because the oil broke up and evaporated. So we really need to make sure that whatever oil spill response we have is adequate to the task ahead of us, and from the Auditor-General's view there is some doubt that we have adit equate equipment to meet that task. I have got a book somewhere in my shelves which I acquired from the seamen's union; when 1. went on board the Trans-Tasman trader from Brisbane to Auckland some years ago they kindly gave me a book, a history of their union. I must admit it took me an hour and a half of getting my ear bashed in order to be awarded it. Rather diplomatically, I might add, I came second in the darts competition, allowing the leading trade unionist on board the vessel to actually win the darts competition. So I won this book. At any rate, there is a chart in the book which highlights the number of known wrecks there have been over the years along the coastline of Australia. It is amazing to see the number: hundreds, in fact, and many of them on the Great Barrier Reef. It is worth making the point that, just because there is an accident at sea with an oil spill, it does not necessarily mean the end of the world: the oil can evaporate and break up, and the reef can recover. There has been a tremendous amount of oil spilt on the reef, particularly during Second World War, so all of these things need to be taken into account. The opposition supports these sensible moves-as it has done over the past several years-to ensure that we are doing everything that we can, through this parliament, to protect the Great Barrier Reef, the jewel in our national tourism crown. This is something that I am pleased to see that the Australia shipowners and the various oil companies support. With a sensible approach, we can be doing our best to enhance the safety of the Great Barrier Reef. I can assure the Minister for Transport and the House that the opposition will again be supporting the government initiative on this issue. New Directions in Australia's Overseas Aid Program

Speaker: Mr BILNEY
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: Kingston-Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs)-by leave-In my last annual report to parliament on the aid program, which I tabled at the end of 1993, I set out the government's approach to poverty alleviation through its aid program. In that report, I emphasised the importance of sustainable economic growth and social development proceeding in tandem. The report I am tabling today highlights significant new directions in Australia's aid program in the social sector and in the area of humanitarian relief. The report also covers the major achievements of the aid program over the past 12 months, and I shall begin my comments by outlining some of the most important of these achievements. Despite the need for continued budgetary restraint in order to consolidate the economic recovery in Australia, the government demonstrated its commitment to international development by increasing Australia's aid program by 3.6 per cent in real terms. This meant that we were one of only four of the 21 OECD donors who increased their aid programs in the last year. As a result, Australia continues to remain above the average for donors in terms of the aid to GNP ratio. Aid volume apart, there have been significant changes in our region, not least in Indochina and the South Pacific. Further afield, the transition to democracy in South Africa will change the the nature of economic relationships throughout southern Africa. I draw attention now to significant developments in Australia's relationship with the South Pacific. During the run-up to the South Pacific Forum-which was held in Brisbane in August last year-I gave a speech to the Foreign Correspondents Association, highlighting the need for policy reforms in the. region. The overriding theme of my address was the need for the region's governments to develop improved national policies to encourage sustainable social and economic growth. I am pleased to say that this theme was taken on board by regional leaders and, as a result, the forum generated an unprecedented level of commitment to improve economic and environmental policies, particularly in forestry. Just recently, a code of conduct on logging was agreed by officials from forum island countries, and only last week a meeting of the region's finance ministers took place in Suva, at which crucial policy issues were discussed, including fiscal, forestry and civil aviation matters which have been identified as priorities by island leaders. In Papua New Guinea, we have agreed on a radical transformation of the aid program. By the end of the decade, the program will have completely moved from budget support to jointly programmed project activities. In Indochina---one of the poorest regions of the world, where annual incomes per head are less than $400---our aid program is panding rapidly. In May 1994, we announced a four-year, $350 million package, targeted the high priority areas of health, infrastruction ture, education, human rights and the strengthening of legal institutions. One of the most visible examples of the effectiveness of our development assistance is the Mekong River Friendship Bridge. It is the first road link between Laos and Thailand and will yield substantial economic benefits to both countries. Moreover, as one of the highest profile aid projects undertaken by Australia in recent years-and incidentally, project completed ahead of schedule and under budget-the bridge is an invaluable showcase for Australian capabilities in major infrastructure design and technology transfer. I wish to draw members' attention government's response to the tragedy of Rwanda. The government has so far contributed $35 million to support the relief effort there, a contribution matched by an extraordiway nary public response of over $30 million. Australia's response was one of the earliest and, from my observations, one of the most effectively targeted of all donors. At the same time, and despite our limited resources, have begun an increased program to support the peaceful transition to majority rule in South Africa by providing assistance of million over three years. This program has been designed to meet the objectives of the Government of National Unity's reconstrucon tion and development program, including through building up capacity in areas such planning, economic policy and the media. There have also been important developments in the sector focus of Australia's aid program. In particular, we have continued expand environmental assistance, and in this financial year, we will spend around $120 million on these activities. Amongst other things, this funding will cover the establishof ment of what we are calling 'Green DIFF', part of the highly successful development import finance facility which has been the catalyst for many Australian companies to become involved in the region. Green DIFF will help to finance environmental projects in areas such as pollution control and energy exefficiency, gaining wider exposure for Australia's environmental expertise. The last at budget also heralded an Australian contribuof nearly $43 million to replenish the global environment facility, as well as an increase in support for the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer. A vibrant private sector is an essential part of the development process. Initiatives such as the private sector linkages program, which last year saw its budget allocation double to $10 million, are targeted at this sector. In addition, the informal sector is now recoga nised as a fundamental resource for social and economic development. Australia's aid program is reflecting this with an increased allocation of funds to micro-enterprise development, with a two-year $1.3 million package for development in the South Pacific and to the South-East Asia. The change in the role of the private sector in development is just one example of the that the aid program has adapted to remain relevant and effective. Another excellent example is provided by this year's launch of the policy document Towards a sustainable future: ecologically sustainable development we through Australia's development cooperation program. I am sure that the shadow minister at the table, the honourable member for Mayo $30 (Mr Downer), would agree that this is a catchy title. Australia's policy in this area fully takes into account the UN Conference Environment and Development in Rio by defining the importance of integrating the as economic, ecological and social dimensions of development. The past year has also seen the government continue to pursue policies on human rights to and good governance through the aid program. On human rights, Australia's policy is to maintain a consistent and principled stand against abuses, while stressing the importance continued engagement through dialogue and institution building. On good governance, Australia's policy encourages the effective management of social and economic resources in developing countries in a manner that is open, transparent, accountable and equitable. As you can see, over the past year we have continued a process of review and adaptation which will ensure that Australia's aid program continues to be of the highest quality, responpopulation sive to the needs of developing countries and appropriate to Australia's place in the world. I would now like to turn to new developments in our overseas assistance in the social sector. The government's policy framework for poverty reduction has three components: firstly, encouraging sustainable economic growth; secondly, investment in human resources through education, health, capacity building and social sector development; and thirdly, provision of safety nets and poverty targeting, including humanitarian relief. The social sector provides a crucial contribudget, bution to sustainable social and economic development. Recent World Bank reports have highlighted the major role that government commitment to social sector development, particularly in education, has played in the rapid growth of many Asian economies. Reflecting this importance, the past two budgets have seen a significant upgrading of the already high priority given to the social sector in the aid program through the introduction of major population and health initiatives. In the 1993-94 budget, we trebled expenditure on the population sector with a four-year, $130 million initiative. To ensure the effectiveness of this initiative, the government commissioned an independent inquiry into the links between population and development. This was one of the most comprehensive surveys of population and development issues ever undertaken, and its conclusions have been vital in highlighting the complex links between population and development. The results of this inquiry have helped AIDAB to develop a range of principles which now guide our aid program's population activities. Among the most important of these principles is that access to safe and effective family planning services is a fundamental right, and that women should have access to a wide range of reproductive health services and should participate fully in defining the services they need. Above all-and I want to emphasise this as much as I cancoercion has no place in the Australian aid program's family planning activities. The priority which the aid program gives to issues was reflected in the major role that Australia played at the International Conference on Population and Development, held in Cairo in September 1994, at which I was present. Helped by our efforts, the conference adopted a groundbreaking program of action for the empowerment of women and called for major increases in global resources for family planning and health activities. I would also like to refer to the significant developments in the nature of our assistance to the health sector. Funding for health was given a major boost in the 1994-95 aid with the introduction of a four-year initiative targeting four priority areas: malaria, polio, neonatal tetanus and HlV-AIDS. This initiative involves additional funding of $110 million over the next four years, which nearly doubles Australia's current spending on health under the aid program. As with our assistance to the population activities, AIDAB has developed a set of principles which will guide this new funding. These principles state that improvements in health are best achieved through an integrated approach which tackles the causes of poverty and improves the status and well-being of vulnerable groups, particularly women and children. Changes are also afoot in Australia's program of assistance to education and training. It is true that assistance to the education sector has always been a large part of the aid program. At present, the sector receives an allocation of a little under 20 per cent of the total budget. The majority of that funding goes towards assistance at the tertiary level. We are now reviewing our assistance in this sector with a view to diversifying the kinds of assistance to include increased support for basic, technical and vocational education. There is no doubt of the social, economic, health and population gains that are derived from basic education. At the same time, the primary responsibility for the provision of basic education lies with the recipient governdemonstrated ment-aid should not substitute for that responsibility. That means that our assistance to the education sector must be carefully targeted to assist and strengthen, rather than replace or duplicate,the efforts of national governments. Finally, I would like to talk about developments in the humanitarian relief program. One of the most tragic features of the past few years has been the continued increase in the frequency and the impact of international emergencies. In the past five years, over 300 million people have been affected by natural disasters and civil strife. Over the past 20 years, the number of refugees has risen from an estimated three million to 23 million, half of whom are children and most of whom are from developing countries. That is a huge cost in human terms. It is also a huge financial cost. Just to give two examples: the annual expenditure of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees has risen from $US450 million in the mid-1980s to $US 1.1 billion in 1993, and the cost of UN peacekeeping operations has risen from under $US 1 billion in 1991 to over $US4 billion in 1993. And it is tragic that this trend shows sign of slowing. The forces which drive this situation are highly complex and demand an equally complex international response. Factors such as the link between poverty and vulnerability, the increase in political volatility since the end of the Cold War and the proliferation of humanitarian relief agencies have to be taken into account in providing a coordinated response. It was against this backdrop of increasing complexity and growing demand for assistance that early last year AIDAB undertook an extensive review of its refugee and relief program. The results of this review are helping the government to update Australia's response to international humanitarian emergencies. The review found that Australia's spending on humanitarian relief had not followed the rapid increases of other donors. This relative decline in funding for humanitarian emergencies is in stark contrast to the clear wishes of the ing paper: Australian public, which has repeatedly that it wants our government to respond generously to such humanitarian tragedies as those witnessed in Rwanda. AIDAB is already responding to the recommendations of the review and is also exploring opportunities for increasing funds for humanitarian relief. As Australia improves its aid response to international humanitarian emergencies, we also share a responsibility with the international community to do more to prevent disasters and complex emergencies from happening in the first place. This is a priority that requires a range of strategies addressing the underlying causes of dispute and conflict. We require improvements in prevention and response strategy through arrangements which minimise threats to security, promote confidence and trust, and create frameworks for dialogue and cooperation. We must also develop peace-building activities to ensure that conflict does not arise in the first place or, if it does, to ensure that it does not recur. That involves strategies which encourage economic and social development, environmental protection, human rights and good governance. Australia will be doing as much no as possible through the aid program to support these activities. In the years ahead, I am confident that Australia will continue to deliver a compassionate and effective aid program that has a real impact on the lives of millions of people throughout the developing world. As I have said before, Australia's future, and the Australian people, demand nothing less.
