Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: by leave-I welcome the opportunity to say a few words on the issue of overseas aid. As I think the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney) would be aware, on this side of the House we· believe that the purpose of foreign aid is to provide for basic needs in two respects: first, in terms of humanitarian assistance; and, secondly, in terms of assisting with sustainable economic growth. It is important, though, in the context of this debate to outline what aid should not be. It should not be some kind of high level bribery or foreign policy instrument which is cynically used to advance a political interest rather than to advance those basic needs that I spoke of earlier. Secondly, aid should not be used as a way of circumventing GATT rules on international trade and subsidising exports. That is not what our aid program is supposed to be about, and in too many countries around the world aid programs are used for those objectives rather than the fundamental objective of the provision of basic needs. We on this side of the House have for many years emphasised the need for community based project aid and have expressed in general terms our reservations about what often become big, white elephant, so-called infrastructure projects. Some of them are fine, but we have expressed reservations about there being too much emphasis in our aid program on those sorts of projects. I wish to address three or four of the issues that arose from the minister's statement. The most controversial issue involves how much aid the government provides. In his statement, the minister claimed that the government demonstrated its commitment to international development by increasing Australia's aid program. That statement is completely disingenuous and the minister knows that it is. That statement can be measured against three sets of standards: firstly, the standards which the Australian Labor Party set itself before the last election; secondly, world standards; and, thirdly-and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) likes to do this in relation to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard)-the standards of the previous government. During the 1993 election campaign the Labor Party promised to achieve an aid target of 0.4 per cent of GDP by 1995. Mr Bilney-What is your policy?

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: Forget our policy. Do you remember your own policy, Minister? Do you remember going out there and promising that you would reach the 0.4 per cent target? Of course the minister remembers it, and of course the Prime Minister remembers it. How has the Labor Party measured up to its own standards? According to the Australian Council for Overseas Aid, the Labor government's pre-election pledge to achieve 0.4 per cent of GNP by 1995 was broken only six months after the election. So the government set a standard, recklessly and deceptively, knowing that it would never achieve it. What it has achieved is 0.34 per cent-from my recollection of last year's budget, that was the figure. It would just about crack 0.33 per cent, in fact. That is well short· of what the Labor Party promised Australians at the last election. So, according to its own standards, the Australian Labor Party has failed in this area. The government did something that it should not have done: it said one thing to the Australian people and, on being re-elected, went off and did another thing. If the government intended to reduce aid as a proportion of GNP, why did it not tell the people? Why did it tell them something else? Why did it try to get the votes of the aid groups in the community and of all those Australians who are interested in aid-which is quite a lot of people-by telling them one thing and doing another? You can get away with it once, but you will not get away with it twice. What about the government's performance against the standards of the rest of the world? Interestingly enough, it was AIDAB which gave me these very good charts. Here is one which deals pretty effectively with the minister's claim that somehow Australia has performed well by OECD standards. This chart shows movements in aid to GNP ratios, conveniently from 1982-83 to 1993-over the life of the Labor government. Of all the countries on the OECD Development Assistance Committee, Australia comes second last. Only the United States has a worse record than Australia in that period. That information was given to me yesterday by AIDAB. Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to table the chart so that the House has the opportunity to peruse the work of AIDAB and the record of this government: a record which does not match its rhetoric. Leave not granted.

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: The shame of it. I will make sure that this is circulated to the offices of all Labor members because I think they should read it. The government should not say one thing and turn around and do another. The minister claimed in his speech that Australia is above the average for donors in terms of aid to GNP ratios. That is funny. The information from AIDAB shows the unweighted average and the weighted average in 1983. Obviously, the unweighted average should be used. In 1983, Australia was not far above the average, but we were above it. Today, according to AIDAB, we are there and the average is there. It is way below. Here we have the mystique of the weighted average where just about the whole of the weighting is taken up by the United States and Japan; it is under the falsest of all ways of trying to measure your generosity in terms of aid. You know the unweighted average is the only intellectually honest average to use. You are trying to tell the aid community that we have a target of 0.4 per cent. When an election comes you abandon it. You are saying that we are being very generous and that we are above the OECD average because we have worked out some sort of construction of a weighted average which, if I may say so, is the most fanciful piece of actuarial work that I have seen in a very long time. On the basis of the unweighted average, we are way down. But the most crippling piece of evidence for the Labor Party is that, according to AIDAB itself, our record was the second worse in the OECD over the last dozen years-that is, while Labor has been in office. Against the standards of the previous government, I do not really need to elaborate, except to say in 1982-83, when we were above the OECD weighted and unweighted averages, Australia's aid was 0.5 per cent of GNP. During the life of the Fraser government, we had a record that has never been closely matched by the Hawke and, of course, now Keating governments. If I could turn to some of the program issues and make a few points about them, first of all, given that the Jackson report was many years ago, there should be a full and independent review of Australia's cooperation development program. I do not know whether the minister and the government are planning to do that in the near future, but it would be a constructive initiative. If it does not do it within the next year, we will do it during 1996. The Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs can look forward to reading about it. In your particular case, you will be lucky to know anything about what we are doing in government unless you read the newspapers because you will not be a member here. Kingston is a seat that we look forward very much to taking. Mr Grace-Promises.

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: We have certainly nearly won it on several occasions, and we have been creeping up at every election. It got very close last time. The second point, though, is in relation to educational assistance and development. The government and the minister claim that nearly 20 per cent of the total aid budget is spent on education. That sounds quite good when you put it that way. But, as the minister pointed out, the vast majority is in fact spent on scholarship assistance at the tertiary level. To be fair-and I always am fair-the minister's own statement of the need to review assistance in the educational sector, to use his words, 'with a view to diversifying the kinds of assistance to include increased support for basic technical and vocational education' is a good statement and is very much in line with coalition policy. The more you read our statements and start to implement them, the more support you will get that from us. There will be no hypocrisy from us. My third point relates to Australian sponsored training scholarships. In the ASTS scheme, the recipient government nominates students, who are usually officials in key positions in that country's public sector, to study in Australian tertiary institutions. The minister concedes the point that, with so much weight given to that program, our contribution in terms of education is not as effective as it could be. I was. glad to read what the minister had to say on that count in his speech. As far as health is concerned, the Australian Council for Overseas Aid says that only 3.6 per cent of bilateral aid is spent on health. I do not know whether the government agrees with that figure. Over the years, health has been a seriously neglected aspect of our aid programs, so we would welcome the greater focus on that issue. There are things that are good and there are things that are less good in what the government has been doing here. I tum to the issue of aid and human rights. The link between aid and human rights must be reviewed very carefully. Obviously, we have to avoid hurting people who are the innocent victims of regimes which show no respect for human rights. That is a very important point to make. The answer I suppose is to decrease the reliance of government to government aid in those circumstances and to increase aid delivery to the community level through AIDAB and non-government organisations. This government basically rejects the link between aid donations and human rights. That has been the rhetoric of the government and, on many occasions, certainly the activity of the government. However, the government has suspended aid to Burma until the SLORC makes clear-cut reforms. Is the government, in rejecting any link between aid and human rights, turning around and saying that it has a different policy in relation to Burma? Or is it conceding that there is a role for human rights and decisions about aid volumes and directions? The government cannot have it both ways. I think the government needs to make its position on that issue much clearer than it is at the moment. The government has shown a great deal of enthusiasm for increasing aid to Vietnam. When the Prime Minister visited Vietnam, he announced a very substantial increase in aid. That country, which is now by far the largest recipient of Australian aid in Indochina, does not have a great record on human rights. Vietnam's record on human rights has not been of much concern to the government. But, quite rightly, the government has been concerned with Burma's record on human rights. The government needs to think through-as I think it does generally with its foreign policy-a lot more carefully where human rights fit into its aid policy so as to articulate a clear and coherent policy. Then those opposite can escape from charges of hypocrisy as everybody will know where they stand. The problem with so much of this debate aboQt aid is that the rhetoric comes out to suit the moment, but the principles underlying the policy are never clear. I think we have established that matter pretty clearly in the course of this debate. I would like to raise many other matters but, to be fair to the other honourable members, time does not permit. In summary, the coalition welcomes the fact that this statement has been made. It provides an opportunity for some discussion on this crucial issue. We urge greater focus on basic health, education and other community level developments in our aid program. We have been concerned about some of the massive infrastructure projects, of which I spoke earlier. We have to be very careful about the way in which those things are handled. We need to be particularly cautious about the downstream economic benefits that might flow to the recipient country. We need to review the trade subsidy levels as a percentage of the aid budget. Those levels look high-although I understand the economic arguments. I think a great deal more thought needs to be given to that matter. We need to clarify and implement human rights principles in our aid program that are coherent and consistent. As I said earlier, we also need a comprehensive review of a development cooperation program in this country. It is well overdue now, as many years have past since the last independent review was carried out. We need further debate in Australia about the nature of our aid, its direction and its underlying principles rather than just one question being asked of the amount of aid provided. Obviously, you cannot be trusted in relation to the amount of aid provided. It does not matter what you say before the next election because, in the unlikely event of your getting re-elected, what you actually do will be totally at variance with what you say. Forget making any promises on that front, because nobody will believe them. If you address some of those other issues, I think the aid program might start to come together a little more coherently. NA Members' Interests Committee

Speaker: Mr GRACE
Title: COMMITTEES
text: -In accordance with standing order 28A, on behalf of the Committee of Members' Interests, I present the report on the operations of the committee for 1994. Corporations and Securities Committee

Speaker: Mr STEPHEN SMITH
Title: COMMITTEES
text: -On behalf of the parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, I present the committee's advisory report on the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill 1994, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee. Ordered that the report be printed.

Speaker: Mr STEPHEN SMITH
Title: COMMITTEES
text: by leave-The First Corporate Law Simplification BilL1994 was referred to the committee by the House on 8 February 1995 for consideration and report to the House by 27 February 1995. On 27 February, the House agreed that the time for presentation of the committee's report be extended to today. The bill amends the Corporations Law and is the first bill under the corporate law simpliraised fication program. The bill deals with share buybacks, proprietary companies and registers. A feature of the bill is its plain English style and language. Following its referral by the House, the committee examined the bill, having particular regard to matters raised during the debate on the bill in the House on 8 February. The committee referred matters raised in debate in the House to the corporations law simplification task force and other interested bodies for their response. On Wednesday 22 February, the committee conducted a public hearing on the bill in Melbourne. The witnesses who appeared before the committee included representatives of accounting bodies, the Law Council of Australia, the Australian Finance Conference and the simplification task force. On Tuesday 28 February, the committee held further discussions with the simplification task force and with Mr Leigh Hall, chair of the Corporations Law Simplification Consultative Group. The committee acknowReport ledges the considerable effort of all those who have participated in the task force's consultative process and those who have provided the committee with submissions or who appeared before the committee at its public hearing. The committee notes that an extensive consultative process has been undertaken Report during the preparation and drafting of the bill. The bill has received general support from the investment, professional and user groups interested in the bill. The starting point of the committee's report is that, subject to specific matters mentioned in its report, the committee considers the bill should be passed by the parliament. Having said that, in relation to a number of concerns raised with or by the committee, where strong or different views were firmly held by individual members ·of the committee, the committee endeavoured to be of most assistance to the House by seeking to find as much common ground as possible and openly make on-balance judgments and leave some issues for consideration by the Attorney-General and debate in the parliament. I deal in turn with some principal issues about the bill which the committee has examined in some detail. The first concern was whether the division of proprietary companies into small and large companies as proposed by the bill be adopted, or whether a reporting entity test proposed by the accounting bodies be adopted. The committee found this a difficult matter to resolve. The committee concluded on balance that the test proposed by the bill should be adopted, as the reporting entity test does not provide a test of sufficient certainty to allow an objective assessment to be made of whether a company falls within the reporting entity test when compared with the small-large distinction provided in the bill. Particularly in view of the Australian Securities Commission submission that the test in the bill provides a simple and objective test which, from a regulator's and a company's view point will not lead to any uncertainty about whether the requirement to lodge accounts applies, the committee concluded that the small-large test be supported over the reporting entity test. By way of aside, I should make the point that on this issue Senator MCGauran has provided the House with a dissenting report. The second concern was whether the criteria proposed in the bill for distinguishing between small and large proprietary companies be adopted in whole or in part. The test proposes that a company would move from a small to a large proprietary company when it had two out of the following three criteria: more than 50 employees, a gross operating revenue of more than $10 million, and assets of more than $5 million. The simplification task force indicated that the effect of using a one out of three test would cause more companies than desirable to fall within the large company category. The practical effect of setting up a one out of three test would negate the intended effect of the scheme, namely, to reduce the unnecessary regulatory burden on small business. The task force also indicated that the effect of setting up a three out of three test would be to impose an unnecessarily restrictive test which would undesirably limit the number of large companies that would be obliged to prepare accounts. The committee has found the resolution of questions about an appropriate test for defining a small or large proprietary company extremely difficult. The committee believes that, of the three criteria provided in the bill, the tests of assets and turnover are far and away the most important. The committee believes these two tests must be included in criteria for distinguishing small from large proprietary companies. The committee was much less convinced that a necessary test for distinguishing a small company was whether a company has more than 50 employees. The committee was unable to reach an unqualified view on the test, and believes that the Attorney-General should give serious consideration to two options, namely, that the 50 employees criterion should remain, or that the test of more than 50 employees be deleted from the bill and the test for a small-large proprietary company be on the proposed assets and turnover criteria. The third concern was whether a register of debenture holders as provided in the bill should be public. The committee considered that convertible debentures should be treated in the same manner as shares and options and that the bill not be changed so far as it relates to convertible debentures. However, there seems to be insufficient reason to automatically treat other debentures in the same manner. The committee recommends that a register be kept of debentures, other than convertible debentures, but that access to the register should be subject to the same Australian Securities Commission power of exemption as at present, together with the privacy regime implemented by the bill. A range of other issues were considered in some detail by the committee. One was the number of shareholders and directors in a proprietary company. In relation to the creation of single member proprietary company, as proposed by the bill, the committee has accepted that there should be single member companies. This change will particularly do away with the perennial problem of twoperson companies where a company has two directors, with one director an 'active' director, and another director--often a spouse or partner-a 'silent' director. The silent director has usually taken no actual role in the running of such companies. The situation which has arisen all too often is that a company fails, due to no fault of the silent director. The resulting financial problems for a silent director, who is usually jointly liable for the failed company's liabiliASC ties, is often referred to in the case of spouses as 'sexually transmitted debt'. The bill proposes the incorporation of small business guide in the body of the Corporations Law. Some members of the committee had significant reservations about this method of drafting, believing, as a matter of principle, that material not forming part the law should not be included in legislation. The committee believes the inclusion of the guide in the Corporations Law is an innovation tive measure, and considers that any risk poses is outweighed by the benefits it promisconscious es. The committee has, however, recommendconsultative ed that inclusion of the guide in the act itself be subject to review by the Attorney-General after it has been in operation for a reasonable time. In relation to provisions governing the audit of accounts of proprietary companies, the committee would be concerned at any waterthis ing down of prescriptions as to who can audit the financial records of a registered company. The committee does not consider that the matters raised by the accounting bodies requires an amendment to the bill, but expects that the problem highlighted by the accountwill ing bodies in their submission and evidence will be addressed by the audit and accounting working party set up under the simplification process. The Corporations Law confers considerable discretion on the ASC in its power to require preparation of financial reports, and in many other areas. The ASC already publishes policy statements indicating the way in which it will administer the Corporations Law, practice notes for the guidance of practitioners on reporting and compliance matters, and class orders modifying the law in relation to classes or persons. However, the committee does not believe that a broad examination of the use by the ASC of its discretionary powers is approthose priate in the context of this bill. Given that the ASC intends publishing its guidelines in respect of requiring small prostarted prietary companies to prepare accounts, the committee considers that the bill should passed in its present form in this respect. The committee, however, also believes that the should prepare a quarterly report to the Attorney-General stating the reasons it has given in the relevant quarter for requiring a small proprietary companies to prepare accounts, and that the report provided to the Attorney-General be tabled in parliament. I wish to make some concluding comments about the simplification process itself. As part of of its statutory duties to monitor the national scheme laws, the committee has monitored the establishment and progress of the simplificaprocess and the consultative process it which that has involved. The committee is that, due to its extensive nature, the process will occasionally give rise to provisions that do not meet the approval of all groups in the process. The inquiry has shown the committee a number of examples of such a situation. However, in the light of recent discussions with the task force and during the inquiry into bill, the committee is satisfied with the effectiveness of the task force's consultative process. Indeed, the committee is strongly of the view that the process followed by the task force is a great improvement on past practice and supports its continuation. The committee continue to monitor the simplification and consultative process as part of its role of scrutiny of the administration and development of the national corporate law scheme.

Speaker: Mrs BISHOP
Title: COMMITTEES
text: by leave-I came to the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities as a newly appointed member after the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill had been introduced into the House. My initial concern, as I said at the time, was that one of the intended consequences of the bill could well have been that the Labor Party would have the opportunity of no longer filing accounts for its operative companies which deal with its money, finance its elections and deal with its property. I set concerns out in my speech in the second reading debate. When I came onto the committee and to look at the bill in totality, I saw that there were some matters of quite considerable be concern that needed to be investigated to a greater extent. The report as it is being presented today, recommending that the legislation be passed, has dealt with some of the concerns in a satisfactory way, but some remarks need to be made to indicate that there are ongoing concerns which may have to be dealt with in the future. Clearly, the most contentious issue was the decision to introduce a new test for which proprietary companies should be required to lodge their accounts and returns with the Australian Securities Commission and which companies should not. This is not a novel proposition in that the situation already exists where companies are broken into those required to file and those not required to file. The old test was the exempt and non-exempt test-a complicated test. The simplification process should be commended, but there are some examples in the bill where, in an attempt to simplify, we are perhaps slipping into some shoddy practices. The member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) may address some of those in his remarks, as he made the point quite well during the committee hearing. There are one or two others as well. To turn to the most contentious issue: the introduction of the new test of when you shall be required to file accounts and when you shall not be required to file accounts is now known as the small-large test. That means that, under the current bill, if you are a company and you meet two out of three criteria set down in the bill, you will be excused from filing your accounts. I asked: why were these three criteria chosen? What sort of evidence was presented to the consultative group or, indeed, to us as members of the committee that said that this is a good way to proceed? Or did somebody just wake up one day and say, 'This looks like a good idea'? The answer seems to be that there was a paper prepared for the consultative group. In evidence the chairman of that group---and he spoke with the committee-said that there is such a test in operation in the United Kingdom and New Zealand and he thought in Canada but he could not remember. Upon further inquiry it became apparent that the United Kingdom had the two out of three test, but New Zealand, which has more recently introduced a test for large and small, has a two out of two test. The chairman of the committee has already addressed the fact that we had a large number of submissions dealing with a different form of test altogether. But once the committee had decided that it was interested in recommending the largesmall test, the question of what criteria should be met became a focus. It is important to say that what became apparent is that the system we are introducing has been lifted from the United Kingdom system. When I asked the following question of one of the members of the task force: 'Was our system just like the United Kingdom system?', he said, 'It's very close, but we had to make some adjustments on money.' I will go into that in a minute. When it came to the New Zealand question, we had no evidence at all. We do not know why New Zealand chose two out of two instead of two out of three. We do not know whether or not the test in the United Kingdom works well or works badly. We saw no evidence. None was brought to the committee. On this very point, I feel that perhaps we should have been in a position to do a more thorough job. I will go to the three criteria that are listed in the bill. They state: A proprietary company is a small proprietary company for a financial year if it satisfies at least 2 of the following paragraphs: (a) the consolidated gross operating revenue for the financial year of the company and the entities it controls (if any) is less than $10 million (b) the value of the gross consolidated assets at the end of a financial year of the company and the entities it controls (if any) is less than $5 million (c) the company and the entities it controls (if any) have fewer than 50 employees at the end of the financial year. If your company complies with two out of the three criteria, you are excused. That is the position in the United Kingdom. The New Zealanders have said that, if you have consolidated operating revenue for the financial year of a set sum of dollars, around $10 million, or if the value of your gross consolidated assets at the end of the year is less than a certain figure-we say $5 million; they have a figure of their own-then you are excused from filing. If it is greater than those two figures, you must file. In this country, if you are a large company which has a gross operating revenue of $12 million a year-so you are above the testand gross consolidated assets at the end of the financial year of $10 million, above the $5 million, and if in the month of May you have 60 employees on your books, you would be caught. You would have to file. But if you decided to fire 15 employees or of the 60 people you had working for you only 45 were employees, the rest were casual, contract labour or the like, you could drop one of the really substantive tests and say, 'We have got fewer than 50 employees, so we are excused. We do not have to disclose what our returns are.' I think that is a test which militates against employment and against allowing sunshine onto the accounts and the affairs of corporations. When we said that we could not form an unqualified view, that is a perfectly accurate statement. It certainly was an unqualified view. We have asked that the Attorney-Generallook further into this matter. In fairness, it would be very sensible if the Attorney-General could take a very good look at the New Zealanders' experience and assess why they rejected the United Kingdom test which we have adopted and how well or how badly it works for them. There was some confusion even in the mind of the chairman of the consultative group. When I said, 'If you meet three out of three, more people would be caught,' he expressed a contrary view. That was cleared up later. But the bottom line is that it remained a matter of some ,confusion as to why it was the right or the wrong decision. A couple of other things were quite important. There was an effort originally to show that the professions that were affected by this legislation were all gung-ho and in favour of it. That is not true either. The Law Council of Australia was split. The insolvency committee said: To suggest to people in business that certain advantages are available only while their companies remain "small" is short sighted and counter-productive. However, the corporate committee of the Law Council of Australia thought it was a great test. So there is confusion in the ranks. The Institute of Chartered Accountants and the CPAs said they did not like the test and wanted another test. There is still a lot of debate out in the community. The other thing it is important to say is that, whilst we are introducing simplified legislation, let us do what we say. We are moving to have legislation that says when Fred Smith, businessman, or Joanna Smith, businesswoman, picks up a piece of legislation, he or she can see what it really means. But, still, in the body of the drafting we have definitions by implication. We have a list that we have defined within the body of the legislation as to who can be a proprietary company, who is eligible to be subject to the large-small test and who is not. A public company cannot be a proprietary company; but we do not say what it is to be a public company. A note to me this morning from the corporations law simplification program said that there will be another bill coming in. I look forward to that. By implication, the bill defines what you have to be to be a proprietary company. If you do not fit that, you are a public company. But then there is an additional definition saying that a company which is limited by both shares and guarantee may not be a proprietary company. That is new, but it makes it clear. I think it would have been sensible to add that a company that is limited by guarantee alone is also a public company. Somebody who picks up the legislation could then clearly read it rather than having it implied from the new section 116 which, by implication, defines a public company. This bill is a good start and the work of the committee of this House is going to be more important as we proceed. One of the implicit difficulties with moving to plain English in an attempt to simplify the law is that you can create uncertainty instead of certainty. By moving away from certain set legal phrases which have defined meanings we could move to new phrases which have undefined meanings; and uncertainty can result. That is why I felt very sympathetic to Mr Tanner who has concerns about putting the small business guide into the act. This is a beginning. I commend the idea of making law readily available to people because I have a fundamental problem with the concept that the law shall be the law by which we are bound but ordinary folk find it incomprehensible. For the same reason, I hope to goodness that one day we will move to some sensible simplification in the area of tax law. But at least in this area we have begun, with the requirement that the Australian Securities Commission will now flag its guidelines as to when it will require additional proprietary companies to file. We are starting to see some accountability return in that area as well.

Speaker: Mr TANNER
Title: COMMITTEES
text: by leave-I, too, applaud the work of the corporations law simplification task force and also the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) in heading down this path to simplification of the Corporations Law. I will make a couple of comments on some of the matters raised by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop). With respect to the absence of any reference in our report to the company being limited by guarantee, we have a difference about that. In my view the position is perfectly clear elsewhere in the legislation, in section 116, which she referred to. It was unnecessary for us to make reference to that. This issue, to the extent that it will be dealt with in any way by simplification processes, will be dealt with in a subsequent bill. It should be noted that this is the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill 1994 and deals only with certain sections of the law. I would also like to refer to the question of the so-called small-large test and, in particular, the limb with respect to 50 employees. I disagree with the suggestion of the member for Mackellar that that militates against employment. I think it is beyond comprehension that any company will be so motivated to avoid the need to report or to file returns that it would dismiss employees or go through all sorts of convoluted arrangements in order to bring itself below the 50 employees. I do not agree with that concern. However, it is fair to say, as the committee reported, that this particular limb of the test is clearly of lesser importance than the other two limbs. That is, in my view, primarily because it is actually less certain when you consider factors like having full-time and casual employees who may work only every now and then--every few weeks or every few months. Clearly, it is less certain than the other tests with respect to assets and turnover. For that reason, the committee has reported that the Attorney-General should give consideration to the merits of this particular limb of the test. However, the broader point that does prevail on this issue is: where do you draw the line? At one end of the spectrum, we have large proprietary companies that should be filing accounts and reporting. That is obviously in the community's interest. At the other end of the spectrum, we have very small companies for which filing accounts and reporting is an onerous obligation and one that really does not serve any great community or public purpose, but puts the people who are running those companies into expense and difficulty. What we are seeking to do here is to meet two ultimately competing imperatives, and in the middle there are companies in a borderline situation where it would be difficult to have an obvious answer as to whether or not they should report. The trick is to develop a test that is certain. The reason that we ultimately supported the simplification task force's test, rather than the so-called reporting entity test as proposed by the chartered accountants, was the greater certainty of the simplification task force's proposed test. A test should also have companies falling on the right side of the line, depending on whether it is in the public interest that they report or not report. The ironic thing about the view expressed by the honourable member for Mackellar is that-given that she has, in the past, put herself forward as a strong defender of the rights of small business-if it were actually enacted, it would lead to at least some small businesses who, under the task force's regime, would not have to report actually being make included and having to report. They would then be faced with the problem of additional expense, paperwork and a bigger bureaucracy. The intention of this legislation is to relieve that burden. Although I do not question the motives of the honourable member for number Mackellar, I think an unfortunate consequence of her position---or one that may well be-is that people in small business are actually exposed to a greater obligation of unnecessary, at least in some instances, reporting and providing accounts. The final comment I make is with respect to a matter that the honourable member for Mackellar gave me glowing praise for, which, no doubt, I will find difficult to live downlegislation that is, the issue of the small business and its inclusion within the legislation. It fair to say that this is something or innovative step in that a document which purports to be advice about the content of legislation and about what it means-a user's guide-is actually being incorporated as part of the act of parliament. At first blush that offended my notion of what an act of parliament is about. In my view, it is there to create obligations, rights and laws that apply to all of the community; it is not to advise the community about what the law actually is. There are some inherent dangers in that with respect to both judicial interpretation of the law and the rights and obligations of professionals who are advising users of the law. A blurring of the distinction between an act of parliament and advice about an act of parliament is a worry. However, in the spirit of cooperation, I have been prepared to give this the benefit the doubt. Therefore, I feel that the committee's recommendation that the Attorneymade General review the operation of this section of the legislation, at a subsequent point, worthwhile. I would like to place on record that, if this typ- of approach to the process of system. legislation is to spread to other areas, I may not be quite so generous.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: COMMITTEES
text: by law. leave-First, I would like to re-emphasise a point that has been made by a number of speakers. Simplification of laws should not law unintelligible or difficult to identify. It worries me that we have identified in this advisory report of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities on the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill the share buyback provisions, for example, more on the of words than on the degree to which they are understandable. Not only is simplification something that is needed but also it is a matter of consolidating the law. I have long been concerned that, as in this instance, we are adding another bill to the heap instead of consolidating the law and making the law understandable by reference to one bill alone. I would hope that, at the end of this review process, one piece of is introduced which incorporates all guide the amendments, thereby making it a lot is easier for those who need to turn to the law of an unusual to know what the law is. I would also like to compliment the members of the Corporations Law Simplification Consultative Group, particularly Mr Leigh Hall, and the members of the simplification task force. It is essential that, if law is to be changed, those who are practitioners in the field are consulted so that it is not just a matter of modification within the Public Service in Canberra. In that sense the reference to the committee was valuable, although it is very difficult with the sort of inquiry that we made to take account of the views of those who operate proprietary companies, as they are now formed in the exempt category, and to be sure that the new requirements meet the bill. In some respects I am still unhappy with the of version we have reached on the definitions of 'small' and 'large'. Earlier speakers have some reference to the three criteria. I am one of those who believe that the number is of employees really should be excluded because I cannot see how it adds to the New Zealand has moved far further than Australia in modification of their corporations It seems to have learned from the American practice rather than relying peculiarly on our British heritage. I am interested to see that the present Australian government, which seeks to set aside its British connection in so many respects, prefers it in this area. For my part, I would have preferred to follow the New Zealand practice and thereby have only two obligatory criteria. The criteria are the gross operatingrevenlle and the assets of the company, and the number of employees should be excluded. In the report itself we have left the conclusion on that point a little ambivalent. For my part, I am not at all ambivalent; I think it would be far better if we excluded that criterion relating to the number of employees and maintained the requirement that all companies who exceed the gross operating revenue and the assets test figures that are set in the bill to file their accounts. There are several other aspects of the bill which I want to address. The first one that is mentioned in the report is the number of directors. I am concerned that the conclusion has been reached that only one director will be sufficient for a proprietary company under this new category of a small company. I believe that the recommendations of the insolvency committee of the Law Council of Australia, which suggested there was still an advantage in retaining two directors, should have been followed. In part, this is because I have always felt that it is necessary to distina guish a company from an individual and, to the degree to which you make a company identical, I think there is a disadvantage. For all that we refer to sexually transmitted debt in the text of the report, it is my view that having two directors places a greater obligation on an individual running a corporation. I think it would have been preferable to have taken the view of the insolvency committee of the Law Council in that respect. A number of aspects of auditing and accounting standards have been mentioned briefly. However, there is another inquiry now being conducted by the task force and the consultative group into those aspects. I look forward to the bill that will return in due course for us to consider whether or not those aspects should be included. I hope that we will be able to look at that report through the same committee structure. There are a number of aspects of accounting standards and audit requirements which I think could well be included in the legislation, and I hope they shall be in the future, once again, to make the legislation a little more understandable by both members of the accounting profession and their clients. The other two matters in the report to which I referred were, first, there is a capacity within the ASC to require that accounts should be tabled even though the company might be excluded by the criteria prescribed. The committee has concluded that it would be advisable for the ASC to table reasons, through the minister, by reporting on threemonthly intervals the reasons for those requirements. I was very pleased to see that the ASC intends to publish the reporting requirements and, generally, the ways in which it intends to administer the changes to the legislation. But it would be helpful if there were to be tabled by the minister on three-monthly intervals the practice intended to be followed by the ASC-and there is reference to that in paragraphs 283 and 284 of this report. The other matter that I wanted briefly to refer to, as I understand the matter is not to be debated in the Senate, is the fact that my colleague Senator Julian MCGauran has filed dissenting report. There was considerable debate in the committee about the reporting entity test which was favoured by the Society of Certified Practising Accountants, the Institute of Chartered Accountants and by others who gave evidence to the committee. Mr Leigh Hall, the chairman of the consultative group, suggested that he at one stage had also been in favour of that reporting entity test to distinguish between small and large companies. My own view is that it becomes too confusing, and it was on that basis that I accepted the alternative. While I wanted to mention that dissenting report, the majority of the committee certainly felt that the reporting entity test was too confusing and, therefore, should not have been followed. At the same time, I repeat my assertion that the legislation would have been far better if only two of the three requirements now included in the present bill before the House were required; They are that the asset and turnover tests should be appropriate, as in New Zealand, instead of providing the opportunity for the number of employees also to be taken into account. It is important that we simplify legislation. At the same time, when there are changes as fundamental as these and when concerns have been expressed, as they have been, I would hope that the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) does not feel that the legislation is necessarily written in stone. It is legislation that needs be reconsidered from time to time. I hope that when the subsequent reports from the consultative group are before this chamber, we might have an opportunity to perhaps review some of the matters and their practice in the report that is now being adopted into the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill and that, ultimately, we might have a consolidated piece of legislation which would be of far more use to the practising public.

Speaker: Mr MOORE
Title: COMMITTEES
text: by leave-I commend the people who have taken part· in the report from the parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities. When the NCSC bill was introduced, it ran for three days with two speakers; when the ASC bill was introduced by Lionel Bowen, it went for four days with two speakers; and the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill has gone for half an hour with four speakers. The knowledge and interest in company law is quite astonishing-it must be one of the few growth industries left. Along the lines of the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), I purely want to add my caution to some of the developments that have come out of the report. Simplification is a very desirable path. Those who work in company law or in tax. ation law will know that in the last few years it has become an absolute nightmare to try to get to some concrete decisions and finally know where you stand. It is even more so in tax and company law. These movements are in the right direction and are full of good intent but, like all matters of good intent, they are paved with a lot of uncertainty. One of the problems with small business is management. The failure of small business in the main, while it is always blamed on something else, in very large measure is a question of management. The best tool of management is proper accounts, and proper accounts will be kept only if there is a compulsory requirement to report on them. The proposal here brings forward the concept of one director. That is a very fine concept. But a lot of people in business would ask, 'Why do you need this?' In terms of accountability and responsibility, in recent to times there has been a lot of talk about wayward creditors. We have heard about the big ones in the newspapers, but there are thousands of small ones who walk away from bankruptcy petitions under circumstances of loose accounts, no accounts at all or with pure cash situations. Therefore I would like the committee to take into consideration the creditors' and debtors' positions-it is not only the income tax commissioner's particular problem-as they relate to ordinary commerce and the desirability of going to one director rather than having two. The honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) referred to some matters earlier. I think she would have drawn attention to the case of a proprietary company involved in a family law action where, if it is run by one company director and a residual partner, there would be no access to those accounts so they would not necessarily know what was going on. Therefore in a normal family business it would be prudent, I would have thought, to look to those matters. Finally, on the question of audit, when the committee refers this to the expert committee involved I hope that genuine consideration will be given to finding a way to ensure that proper accounts are kept, even on the say-so of the auditor who could state that he has lodged a taxation return based on the corporate accounts. This may be beneficial towards keeping some form of management tool alive and well in small business. NA NA 1995 Second Reading Debated resumed.

Speaker: Ms HENZELL
Title: PROHIBITION AMENDMENT BILL
text: Capricornia) (2.52 p.m.)I have not had an opportunity to read the Hansard of yesterday's debate on the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Amendment Bill 1995, but I suspect we will find an interesting coalescence of points of view from all sides of the House and some strange bedfellows in the debate. But that is all to the good, and I am sure that the majority of people in the House will definitely support the government's record. This amendment bill is aimed to clarify the scope of the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992, and is part of a positive program by the government. We have a very proud record on legislation in this area; in fact, the World Health Organisation sees us as a world leader on this matter. An article by Adrian Bradley in the Australian on 31 May 1994 stated: The nation's anti-tobacco legislation remains forefront of international moves to ban cigarette advertising, providing the World Health Organisation with a blueprint for moves to persuade Western Pacific countries to introduce similar measures. Why is this important? It is important because the World Health Organisation estimates that three million people die each year from smoking related illnesses and it expects this to increase to 10 million a year by the year 2020. In Australia about 3.5 million Australians smoke, representing 28 per cent of people over the age of 18 years. This is falling, with 32 per cent of men and 24.7 per cent of women smoking. Part of that change has been the move away from the availability of advertising. I suspect that, like me, Mr Deputy Speaker Scott will remember the Peter Stuyvesant advertisements - London, Paris, New York-at the Saturday afternoon flicks, which is where we used to go in the world before television. Mr Deputy Speaker may not remember that; he may be too young. But, in those days, overseas travel and all the sophistication that involved was a great model for those of us who aspired to that. Part and parcel of that was cigarette smoking. We have seen a major change due to government policy and a rearguard action from some of the national cigarette companies, culminating in a High Court challenge to some of our legislation. I wish to draw to the attention of the House the need for members in this place to observe the very proper and appropriate rulings of the Speaker and the President in relation to smoking in the precincts of the parliament. There are rules that all employees of .the parliament must adhere to, and it concerns me greatly that certain members in this place feel that it is quite appropriate for them to inflict passive smoking on the rest of us. I urge .all of my colleagues to walk outside if they must smoke. We will try to get away from that cigarette smoke in the garden areas. It is very important that all adults act as effective role models. As we curtail opportunities to promote cigarette messages, one of the important issues we have to address is young people taking up smoking. In her article by the Drug Education Journal of Australia entitled 'Peter Jackson, you're lying: at the education or advertising-which message is more convincing?' Margaret Powell outlines the importance of the communicated message. She states: In our consumer-oriented society, there is another force operating in children's lives. Independence and adulthood are seen to be manifested through appealing images which are used skilfully by advertising agencies to selI products, to sell cigarettes. Despite the wide public acceptance of detrimental effects of smoking among children and their peers, smoking cigarettes is seen to respect independence, maturity, vitality, popularity and success. We find that young people, particularly those in puberty and perhaps even from grade 7, see smoking as an important rite of passage. This is something we have to address not only by removing those public images but also by sending very positive anti-smoking messages and providing children with assertiveness training. It is absolutely essential that cigarette manufacturers not be allowed to sponsor sport or cultural activities. I believe that, as we have continued to curtail this activity, other companies have taken up the slack and are now sponsoring major sporting events. I believe that, when cigarette manufacturers are banned from sponsoring sporting events; the current consumer acquiescenceto sponsorship of sport will also change. The other issue we have to address is the way cigarette companies are using value adding programs to entice young people to smoke. It is certainly something we will have to address because, often, the people targeted are those who are most likely to be affected by smoking. For instance, in the Australian of 3 February 1995, a reference is made to a Senate submission in relation to a Northern Territory individual. The article mentions a promotion being offered to stores in Top End Aboriginal communities. The promotion involves a free T-shirt with the community name on the back and a 'big country'and 'Malboro' advertising slogan on the front. All these initiatives are encouraging young people to smoke and are trying to get around our advertising bans. I look forward to continuing my comments after question time.

In the year ending February 1994, for example, 1.6 million people changed jobs or employers-that is in a labour market of eight million. That is 20 per cent of the labour force in one year-130,000 new positions a month or 4,000 a day. In other words, that constant change in the labour market would mean that those people who line up to protect their minimums or to maintain, for instance, their annual leave loading or their overtime, would find that they were unable to secure it. Let me give you an example. A new typical part-time nurse working 20 hours each weekend would have her pay lowered by $114.80 per weekend. A new transport worker or driver on 12 hours overtime each week would have his pay lowered by $113.35 a week. They are the words of Paul Keating. I will just conclude by saying this: this country is now led by a man who rorted his preselection in order to gain entry into parliament. He is the last person who has any moral authority-either here or anywhere in Australia-to lecture anybody about honesty. As one of my colleagues said to me, he is in need of an honesty transplant but cannot find a donor on the front bench. When it comes to dirty tricks, when it comes to rorting preselection ballots, when it comes to misleading the public, when it comes to lying to the Australian people, there is no 'person better at rorting a preselection than the Prime Minister. There is no person better at telling a l-i-e than the Prime Minister. There is no person better at deceiving the Australian people than the Prime Minister. There is no person who has been more consistently up to his armpits in lying and deceiving of the Australian public than the Prime Minister. All I can say to the Prime Minister is that if he wants to fight the next election campaign on the question of honesty and integrity-oh, I could be so lucky. That is all I can say-oh, I could be so lucky. Prime Minister, please will you fight the election campaign on the issue of honesty and integrity? I would be delighted. I know they say that you do not like me, but actually I think deep down you might. Why don't you do me a real favour and fight the election campaign on the question of honesty and integrity? I will put my honesty and integrity on the line any day against yours. I could not be more delighted. I hope that you do this again. I hope that you do it every week, because it affords us a tremendous opportunity to point out what a deceiving, dishonest, lying politician you really are.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: LEADER OF THE OPPOSITION
text: Fifteen minutes, and not one word about push polling; 15 minutes, and one minute was in defence of himself on this question; 15 minutes, and not one statement about Mr Robb's shenanigans in his national office last week and this week; 15 minutes, and all of it the product of one book handed over to him by Grahame Morris, whose activities have been the subject of very considerable questioning in the media today; 15 minutes solely on a product that had been handed out, retailed, a piece of literature which has been around for donkeys years. What we have not got with John Howard is this: you are allowed to talk about 1969; you are allowed to talk about 1995; but what you are not allowed to talk about is 1977 to 1983. You are allowed to talk about 1929; you are allowed to talk about 1946; but, for God's sake, don't mention the war. Whatever you do, don't mention the war. Also, 'Do not for one minute mention how I got my name honest John.' If ever there was a lucky politician in Australia it has to be the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), because the population in general would now believe that the nickname honest John came from a reputation for public integrity during the time he was a minister. In fact, the nickname honest John was coined at one decisive point: it was coined in 1978 after the 1978 budget in which the Hobart Mercury-the most extreme in terms of its presentation, and with the rest of the AU$tralian provincial dailies all with the same theme---carried on the front page the words 'lies, lies, lies' in huge bold type. They carried those words 'lies, lies, lies' because John Howard had brought down a budget and in that budget was a direct repudiation of all the election promises he had put forward in 1977. So, from that day on until quite recently, honest was accompanied by quotation marks. That is where the title came from. This is a useful opportunity for us to provide the House with a reminder of that point. Generally speaking, in these censure debates the Liberals actually have the courage to stay in the chamber but they have all gone. They went straight out the door, except the poor chap at the table, the member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), who has to sit here and carry the can for his leader because somebody has to sit on the opposition front bench. The member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall), who has covered himself in glory in recent days by his efforts inside the Liberal Party to deal with the issue of push polling, is also sitting here and half of the Independents are sitting here. The others have retreated to lick their wounds because this is a censure debate that they invited upon themselves. We did not start off with the intention of censuring them for this; we merely started off with the inten-:- branch. tion of pointing out a few facts. But members of the opposition said, 'Oh, please, get up and censure us' and so we did. We are obliging fellows and so we got up and censured them. When we did, there was not a single word of reply from the opposition leader to the gravamen of the point. I show to the House the how-to-vote card. I will go through it again because I think it is necessary to debate the point of the censure and argue the toss as to what that point means. If you have got evidentiary documents associated with it, then you might as well table them and go through it. Any person receiving this piece of paper could in no way be misled about where it came from because it has the Australian Labor Party logo sitting there. It has written across the bottoin of the page, 'Authorised by Doug Thompson, Australian Labor Party'. It does not carryon top of it a No. 1 preference because it is handed out in the assumption that the person receiving it is going to vote Independent No.1. It simply carries on down the list from that point onwards. So it is not a bogus how-to-vote card in itself. A bogus how-to-vote card, indeed, might have carried the number '1' upon it. The opposition failed to point out that this was taken up with the Electoral Commissioner for the ACT who, at the end of the day, approved it. I wonder, however, whether he approved this little document from the same election. This little document says: Ratepayersrevolt. Vote 1 Lucinda Spier column B on ballot. It is authorised by P. Jansen of 12 Dampier Crescent, Forrest. Is there a sign on it that says 'Liberal Party candidate'? Is there a sign on this which has the logo of the Liberal Party in Canberra? Is it anywhere on this document? Who is Lucinda Spier? Lucinda Spier is a Liberal Party candidate but there is a bogus how-to-vote card put out for her called 'Ratepayers revolt' . I am afraid, old son, when you start to sling the muck in this particular show, you never know where it is going to stickand it is sticking very solidly on you lot when it comes to the performance of the ACT Mr Howard was very keen to spend a very long time quoting from a book by Edna Carew, a book which has now been in circulation for the best part of a decade, as though anybody in politics has not yet read it.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Title: LEADER OF THE OPPOSITION
text: I haven't!

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: LEADER OF THE OPPOSITION
text: The Prime Minister hasn't. Many others, nevertheless, will have. But we have more recent preselections to discuss than that preselection; we have the one of immediate interest to us. The Canberra branch of the Liberal Party is a pack of classics when it comes to dealing with the issues of an election. It also put out bogus how-to-vote cards with no clarity at all about the origins of those how-to-vote cards. One great thing in politics that you learn very early on is projection: when somebody comes at you, there is a 90 per cent chance that he is coming at you with a problem for himself. And if you get in behind it, you might well find something very interesting as you spend your time going through. My father is a bit of a right-winger in Labor Party affairs. He used to always say to me, which I thought was unduly fair on his behalf, 'I'm afraid to say, Kim, in a union ballot when they scream commo, you scream auditors.' Nevertheless, this is obviously a very similar case that we have here on our hands:. we ought to scream Electoral Commission, having had this particular accusation levelled at us. I have here an interesting report from today's newspaper the Canberra Times. It says 'Top Liberal candidates miss out'. There was an awful lot talked about by the Leader of the Opposition in his 12-minute readings from past literature and his three-minute defence of himself, and that was about people who get ballots and do not actually win elections. The report states: The Liberal candidate for the Canberra by-election did not top the poll of party members for the preselection, according to party informants. Others say the leading candidates who lost, on the Left and the Centre of the party, were subjected to a right-wing dis information campaign that fitted the pattern, if not the depths, of the push-polling campaign against Labor's candidate, Sue Robinson. If you go on and read the rest of this very sorry little report, you will find the statement by the Liberals, 'We don't really care what Liberal Party members feel in this area. There is a little closed purple circle and we will the opinion of the members but we will appoint whom we like at the end of the We'll put them through a poll. It doesn't matter what votes they get in that poll, rorted or otherwise, we are going to select exactly whom we desire. And our own party members article reads: that we would otherwise have thought in good standing, we will subject them to the sort of campaign that Sue Robinson has been subject Liberal to in this situation.' The Liberal Party is very fast off the mark in accusations the subject of honesty. I raised the issue in this parliament yesterwill day, in, I thought, a fairly light-hearted of way, because I do not really want to see Andrew Robb in gaol for six months; nor do I want to see him fined $2,500. I have lower ambitions. I merely wish his leader to repudidoctoring ate him. That is all. I do not want to see him in gaol. I do not want to see shape or form fined. But I would not mind seeing his leader give him a bit of repudiation every now and then. But what did we find? I mentioned it in fairly unheavy fashion because I did not know whether the Liberal Party had cleared with Western Australian lottery commission the particular raffle book that it sent to George Gear's family. I could not have told from document-unlike this document which the Liberals could tell was a Labor Party circulatalleging ed document-whether it had been cleared with the Western Australian gaming commisreason sion because it contained only reference Northern Territory and Australian Capital failing Territory licences. So I left it hanging as to whether anything untoward had happened. What happened? The old push pollers of the Liberal Party-they are no longer tors-including the leader, were up around the gallery saying, 'Beazley's overstepped himbeen self. He's finally caught himself out.' Paul Bongiorno, who runs the evening claquer service for the Liberal Party, made a statement saying, 'The government has clearly overstepped itself as far as this issue is concerned.' I was prepared to let it rest at that and to leave as an open question whether anything had happened. But one of the journalists, hear Lenore Taylor, actually had the presence of mind to ring the Western Australian gaming day. commission. What did Lenore Taylor find when examining the words of the honest push pollers, the honest Leader of the Opposition, the epitome of honesty in his office? Her However, a spokesman for the WA Office of Racing and Gaming told The Australian that the Party had broken the law by failing to include the number of its WA permit on the tickets and said that the tickets had never been seen by the over here on gaming office. "(The Liberal Party) made the mistake and we issue them a warning letter but take no further sort action than that,". . . As I said before, I do not particularly want any action to be taken on the matter. But I am quite enjoying the fact that the Liberals' spin has been revealed for the tissue of lies that it is, as is the case with most of their him in any way, other activities. But I do take exception to the sorts of things that Sue Robinson has been subjected to in Canberra. I take very grave exception to a those. As pointed out by the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition has not repudithe ated those. The reason we have the censure motion in this place is the pathetic effort by the Leader of the Opposition to mislead this that House, in coming forward with a ticket, properly marked by the Labor Party, and that there was something wrong with it-when in fact it had been cleared. The he has done that is that he wants to to crawfish out of the consequences of his to repudiate the people on his staff and the people in the federal office for the various shenanigans that they have got up to, including that most heinous of shenanigans associatspin doced with push polling. I am pleased to say that so far there have three or four editorials on this matter. It has been considered of sufficient weight, dealing with the integrity and honesty in the Australian electoral system. It has not been brushed off by them as a slight matter of no moment. There have been editorials by three or four of our major daily papers saying that this form of activity, this form of defamation, this suggesting that a particular candidate has written books inviting people to go and burn down the houses of the burghers of Canberra-which is what was suggested by the Liberals-and that the candidate endorsed a proposition that people should be entitled to legal terminations of pregnancy at nine months, and a whole plethora of slanderous lies that were incorporated in that push polling technique, should be banned. All of those newspapers had the opportunity, and have taken it, to repudiate this activiThe ty. The only person who still thinks it is a pretty good idea-or, if he does not think it is a good idea, he has taken the view that he will just let it flick past and if the old boss cocky of the Liberal Party decides to pursue it at some point in time he will let that pass too-has been honest John, trying to cover himself with a piece of work that is purely contemptible, but a piece of work which stands in such dramatic contrast with the Liberals' behaviour. There is no doubt that, in the course of political campaigns in which there is a plethora of political parties, political parties will try to take advantage of that situation. But here the Labor Party presents an honest statement. The Labor Party says, 'Put the Liberals last. Authorised by Doug Thompson, Australian Labor Party. If you vote Independent and you want your preference to go to the ALP, this is how you do it.' The Labor Party tells people what it is doing but the 'Ratepayers revolt' put things out with no Liberal Party identification. There is no indication whatsoever where they come from. If you are in the independent minded ratepayers revolt group, just rock on out there and vote Liberal. That is the proposition put forward by the Liberal Party. The Leader of the Opposition invited his personal censure. He gave us no reason why he should not be censured. There is no doubt that, after we have heard from the next Liberal Party speaker, this House is going to take advantage of that opportunity. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr CONNOLLY
Title: LEADER OF THE OPPOSITION
text: Bradfield) (4.55 p.m.}This Labor Party opposite never learns and it never changes. Any sensible analysis of the political activities of the Labor Partyespecially in New South Wales since the 1970s--demonstrates beyond any reasonable doubt that you never learn and you never change. This censure motion today is to complain that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) misled the House with his allegations about how-to-vote arrangements in the ACT. These were not allegations; these were facts. basis of the facts is none other than the documentation, which was circulated to ALP branch workers at the ACT elections and which I hold in my hand. The evidence contained in these documents shows beyond all reasonable doubt that the claims made by the opposition are absolutely correct. The important thing is that neither the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) nor the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) makes any serious attempt to explain the unexplainable. Why is it so? It is because in the ACT election we merely saw a continuation of a long line of cheating, cajolery and activities of this dubious nature that you and your party in virtually every state of Australia-whether it be Queensland, New South Wales or Victoriahave perpetrated for far too long. Let me start with Queensland. There was a by-election in the seat of Mirani. There was a Confederate Action Party candidate. This particular candidate claimed to give his second preferences to the National Party. But was the Labor Party to be outdone on this? Was there any risk to be taken? Of course not. The Labor Party put out its own how-tovote card, which said, 'Make your voice heard in the government by voting for the Confederate Action Party,' but then it said-we are told this is the Labor Party technique-' Don't support Borbidge's bickering coalition. Give your second preference to your Wayne Goss Labor candidate Graeme Hall and do not waste your vote.' Any reasonable person reading that document would say that it had been put out by the Confederate Action Party. Let me now move to what happened in Victoria. The general secretary, Peter Bachelor, issued a bogus how-to-vote card in the Nunawading by-election in the 1980s. Labor denied it but, eventually, you admitted your fault. You admitted that you were cheating. There is two out of two. Now I will move to the ACT, which is the subject of this particular debate. I suggest that in this particular case one can only conclude that the motive was deception. It was deception in its most vile form. For the benefit of those members opposite who may not want to believe what some of their colleagues get up to when they get the opportunity, this is what a preference how-to-vote card looks like a la ALP. Booth captains at the ACT election were told that booths that have preference how-to-vote cards will not have ALP identifiable badges, et cetera. I am a reasonable man. I am sure all my colleagues here are reasonable people. When they are facing a situation like that, they have to turn to that fundamental word 'motive'. If the motive of the Labor Party booth captains was to encourage their booth workers to deliberately disseminate information which they knew to be inaccurate, it is deception. There is no other way to describe it. Further, this document states, 'We want to distinguish between those giving out ALP how-to-votes and those giving out preference how-to-votes.' The key word is 'distinguish'. What was the Labor Party trying to distinguish? Was it trying to distinguish Liberal votes from Labor votes? Was it trying to distinguish Independent votes from Labor votes, or Independent votes from Liberal votes? You do not have to be more than a halfwit to work out that the Labor Party in Canberra and its booth workers knew precisely what they were trying to distinguish, because they have told us. They were trying to distinguish between those giving out ALP how-to-votes and those giving out preference how-to-votes. Why were they trying to do that? They were doing that with a deliberate intention to deceive the electors of Canberra and to make them believe they were voting independent. There it is. They are not my words; it is your document. They are not my thoughts, your intentions. They are not my desires, your deceit. There is no doubt about it. The next document has instructions for handing out preference how-to-vote cardseuphemistically and very appropriately called green slips. The first instruction is: the person handing out the preference how-to-votes should attempt to get the last position in the queue-that is, the position closest to the polling booth-not forgetting that there is a minimum distance of six metres. It was very generous of them to tell us that. Why were they doing that? They were positioning their people deliberately so that, as the electors went into the booth, the last piece of paper they would receive would be this dubious piece of bumf-this dubious piece of papertelling them that if they voted Independent not to give the Liberal!AllianceMr Harry Woods-What's it sayan the bottom?

Title: LEADER OF THE OPPOSITION

Speaker: Mr CONNOLLY
Title: LEADER OF THE OPPOSITION
text: Even you and I can agree on something. The second instruction gives the line to use when handing out the how-to-votes, and this is part of the real substance of the deception. It says that the line used should be something like 'Voting Independent?' Do not forget, we are dealing with people who have no badges on, no distinguishing ALP characteristics at all. Why? Because they were told by the Labor Party to take them off. If that is not deception, would you please tell us what is. People going to the polling booth took this piece of paper, believing that they had the opportunity to exercise their democratic right and vote Independent because it had the word 'Independent' along the top of it. Voters in the ACT did not know the truth; they had no reason to doubt this. They are learning what millions of Australians have learnt in recent days, and it is quite simple: you cannot trust Labor with anything. You really cannot. When you look back on its record, you find that it never learns and it never changes. 1I have demonstrated in this debate thatDr Theophanous interjecting
