Speaker: Mr CONNOLLY
Title: LEADER OF THE OPPOSITION
text: I have demonstrated in this debate that, whether you are talking about by-elections in Queensland or in Nunawading, Victoria, whether you are talking about the rorting of preselections-such as Mr Keating's own preselection in Ne.w South Wales in 1970 or so-nothing changes. This mob cannot lie straight in bed. When the Leader of the House made his great contribution, he complained that my colleagues were not here to listen to him. They had much more sensible things to do. He made one most interesting comment. He talked about presenting an honest statement! The evidence is so blatant. You forgot that the word 'honesty' has a little 'dis' in front of it. It is called dishonesty, and there is a heck of a difference between the two words. A growing number of people in this country have had enough; they want a bit of honesty in government. They want to see the situation improved. They will not see that from a Labor Party which, time after time, has demonstrated so clearly its utter inability to properly improve the situation. 1 turn now to branch stacking. Speaker: Mr CONNOLLY
Title: LEADER OF THE OPPOSITION
text: Thank you, Mr Speaker. A report was brought down on the New South Wales ALP. It was a report by the then federal president, Mr Tom Burns, into the administration of the New South Wales branch of the party. He spoke about the preselection for the seat of Blaxland. Who is the member for Blaxland? What is his name? Paul Keating. Precisely. The report states: The preselection ballot was held on 26 October 1968. There were six candidates ... the action of the New South Wales executive secured the result by allowing supporters who had joined the Party outside of the expressed Party rules to participate. Keating won that preselection because the central office made jolly sure that he did. His friend Laurie Brereton even had his motorbike there to prove it. The important thing is that, from the beginning to the end of this whole sorry situation, time and again this Labor Party is simply incapable of having an honest situation where it sees any prospect whatsoever of getting a benefit. Much has been said by both the Prime Minister and the Leader of the House about the fact that the Leader of the Opposition has not had anything to say about push polling. Mr Leo MCLeay-That's right.

I do not think that that is something that goes under the provisions of giving indulgence to the Leader of the Opposition, but there are other forms of the House which are available to all members to raise those sorts of issues. The Leader of the Opposition has also said to me that he wants to make a personal explanation. That is for members to show where they personally have been misrepresented; it is not for debating or arguments about other extraneous matter. On that basis, because I have two other personal explanations-that is where we are up to in the afternoon's proceedings-I am prepared to give the Leader of the Opposition the opportunity to make a personal explanation to show where he has been personally misrepresented.

Civil Aviation Regulations (Question No. 1663) Mr Sinclair asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 17 October 1994: (1) Will he provide a list of all dispensations to Civil Aviation Regulations which have been (a) granted, (b) withdrawn or (c) varied by the Civil Aviation Authority since 1 January 1993. (2) Which of the dispensations referred to in part (1) are current. (3) With respect to each of the dispensations referred to in part (1), (a) which persons or organisations were affected by the dispensation, (b) what was the term of the dispensation, (c) on what grounds was the dispensation granted, withdrawn or varied and (d) which parties were notified of the dispensation.

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: DATE
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1)&(2) The Civil Aviation Authority has provided the following answer: The Civil Aviation Regulations (CARs) do not provide for formal 'dispensations' as the term is used in this question. However, the CARs do allow for exemptions to be granted for the handling of special or exceptional circumstances. Exemptions which may be granted include: general and specific ex em ptions, permissions, authorities and approvals. The question may also be intended to cover delegations and appointments issued under .the Regulations. In this regard, regulation 7 of the CARs provides for the delegation of the powers and functions vested in the Authority and regulation 6 provides for the appointment of 'authorised persons'. A list of the types of exemptions and delegations, which can be granted under the CARs, is attached. (3) A comprehensive list of the exemptions granted under the CARs would take some time to assemble as, apart from exemptions under CAR 308, the remainder would have to be collated from information held by the Central Office, the Regions, and the District Offices in order to answer the question in the depth that is required. NA NA CAR 308 Exemption Regulation 308 of the CARs is a general exemption power. It provides that the Authority may exempt a particular aircraft or specified type or category of aircraft from compliance with specified provisions of the CARs. It may also exempt persons from compliance with such provisions while they are in, or associated with, the operation craft. An exemption under regulation 308 is a disallowable instrument under section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, and is subject to disallowance by the Parliament. Miscellaneous Provisions Under certain provisions of the CARs, (for example regulation 89ZD, sub-regulation 139(3) the Authority may exempt persons from compliance with the requirements of a particular CAR. Specific exemptions granted under these provisions are not disallowable instruments. Permissions Under numerous provisions of the CARs, (for example regulations 134, 143, 144, 149 and 156) the Authority may give permission for a person or an aircraft to undertake an activity which would otherwise be unlawful. These permissions operate, in effect, as exemptions. Authorised Activities Certain provisions of the Regulations (for example regulations 137,151 and 152) provide for the Authority to authorise activities for particular purposes. Again, authorisations of this kind are essential exemptions under another name. Approved Activities There are provisions of the Regulations (for example sub-regulation 163AA(2), regulation 254) under which the Authority may approve certain activities. These approvals are also exemptions by another name. . Delegations under Regulations 6 and 7 of the CARs Authorised Persons/Delegations Under regulation 6, the Authority may appoint persons to be authorised persons for the purposes of any regulation in which the term 'authorised person' occurs (for example regulation 42J, 42M, 42R and 42Y). Under regulation 7, the Chief Executive Officer of the Civil Aviation Authority may delegate to a person all or any of the Authority's powers and functions under the CARs. In the interest of administrative efficiency, many of the powers and functions referred to in the preceding list have been delegated to officers of the Civil Aviation Authority. The Chief Executive Officer has also delegated the Authority'S powers and functions as necessary, to persons outside the Authority. In particular, the Authority's powers and functions in relation to the testing of flight crew have been extensively delegated to persons outside the Authority. RAAF Base Williamtown (Question No. 1885) Mr Vaile asked the Minister for Transport, of such air1lpon notice, on 31 January 1995: What would be the total cost of upgrading the RAAF air base at Williamtown near Newcastle to . international airport capacity.

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: TYPES OF EXEMPTIONS
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: The Government announced in the 1990 Budget that it had decided to transfer remaining Commonwealth aerodromes to local authorities and to encourage full local ownership for Aerodrome Local Ownership Plan aerodromes. Negotiations on arrangements were held with each local authority involved in the program. To facilitate the completion of the program the Commonwealth provided maintenance grants to bring the aerodromes to reasonable order for the current level of traffic. RAAF Base Williamtown (Newcastle Airport) is owned by the Department of Defence. The civil areas of the airport were the responsibility of the then Department of Transport and Communications, until 18 December 1992 when the Newcastle City Council and the Port Stephens Shire Council agreed to take over responsibility for the civil areas of the airport on long term lease arrangements. The councils now operate the civil area under a 30 year lease from Department of Defence. The Federal Government provided a grant of $2,75 million from the Newcastle Economic Development Program for works at the airport at the time of the transfer. This allowed considerable development work at the aerodrome to be carried out. The councils are responsible for the management of the works and the transfer agreement provides that no additional Commonwealth funds will be provided. Any further upgrading of facilities is a matter for the councils and Department of Defence. Title: HOSTELS FOR RURAL STUDENTS ELEMENT
text: the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs, upon notice, on 7 February 1995: Has (a) the Minister, (b) any member of the Minister's staff or (c) the Minister's office had any (i) bills or accounts paid on their behalf or (ii) equipment provided by their Department or any other organisation for which the Minister has portfolio responsibility since 13 March 1993; if so in each case, (A) in respect of bills, (I) what sum was paid and (II) for what purpose was the bill or account rendered and (B) in respect of equipment, what are the full details. Mr Bilney-The answer the honourable member's question is as follows: All bills or accounts paid and any equipment provided to me, my staff or my office by the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) are in accordance with the 'Guidelines for providing services to Ministers', pp 154-156 in the Ministers of State of the Commonwealth Parliament 'Office Handbook'. No such bills or accounts have been paid by the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research.
